I played this game last year, and just came back to give it a try after i saw the news about some interesting updates.
Sadly, my thoughts remain the same: This game has potential, quite some, in my opinion, and does some things VERY well. 
BUT. All the good things are overshadowed by a single thing, that has ruined multiple times the experience for me and my friends. 
It's not the animations, it's not the mouse weird acceleration thing going on that makes your aim go funky, it's not the graphics, it's not the boredom after just a few days and the repetitiveness of the gameplay... it's the AI. 
THE. F*****G, AI. 
Let me explain: I stopped playing because we would get headshotted by a single enemy controller by the AI running in a field with an SMG and insta-killed. From 200+ meters. With TOP ARMOR. Multiple times.  So you have to respawn in the closest city, run back to your body to get your things back, only to find the bots evaporate you again, and again, and again. And each time you have to spawn further away, because spawns have a cooldown time. Fun, eh?
So we stopped playing out of frustration. 
Then we came back last week because they had "Rebalanced the AI", only to find they kinda did... but there's still a huge underlying issue with the way the devs program difficulty for the harder missions.

Their words:" [i]Getting an instant 180 headshot by an AI using a Mosin is not the experience we are aiming to deliver, and we hope these changes will eliminate that problem"[/i]
I mean, yeah i have multiple videos of me getting evaporated by AIs doing a 180 turn and shooting me with spiderman's reaction time which was kinda bullcrap.
Now? Well, now if you dare to pop your head out of cover you get shot and killed... in 2 shots. I mean, i agree the AI actually turns slower and reacts slower, but we're talking American Sniper's level of accuracy no matter the weapon they use and how far you are. I have videos of AI following me repositioning myself while running hidden from them: use 3rd person, run along a hill, a crest or a shore hidden from view and see how the AI's powerful x-ray eyes follow you wherever you go. 
Oh, and if you dress yourself with a ghillie, set up a .cal50 on a hill and shoot enemies from 500m+, don't expect to live for more than a few seconds. They will kill you with their shoelaces.

This is not "The Dark Souls of Survival FPSs", this is lazy coding.

This game is seriously hardcore. As someone who's not played a game of the genre before, it took me a while to warm to it, with some early frustrations as I kept dying and restarting with nothing. However, after a few hours learning the ropes I managed to get some decent weapons and build some momentum - winning a few firefights and completing a mission. Once you have a basic grasp of the game mechanics and stash some items the experience becomes rewarding and you feel very tangible progress.

Update - 9 July 23:

I've now clocked in 30 hours, so though it would be timely to give an update. I'm getting more and more engaged with the game every time I play it, and it keeps drawing me back week after week. The missions are challenging and varied due to the changing locations, and even outside them you regularly have engagements with wandering patrols and hostiles manning checkpoints and industrial sites.

I've started to work out some of the survival aspects of the game like collecting water and cooking food, and have reached the point where I'm thinking about setting up a base, since my storage in both safe zones is full.

The boats that were fairly recently added to the game are great and I've enjoyed using them to get about when I've found them. Parking the boat just off the shoreline and picking off enemies from afar is a great way to clear perimeter guards before moving in and completing a mission.

I convinced a friend to buy the game and playing in a squad has really amplified the experience. Doing coordinated attacks is great fun and has allowed us to tackle more challenging missions than we could have managed solo. I'm sure you can find other players on the game's discord server if don't have anyone you can rope in.

I have been playing on an official PVP server, which has meant I've had a few run-ins with other players, usually around medium difficulty or higher missions. It's been a mixed bag, but generally wise to treat anyone you encounter as hostile. There was one occasion where I completed a medium mission but then got taken out by someone with a sniper rifle which was somewhat frustrating. But I've also had a couple of times where I've arrived at a mission in progress or just completed and managed to come away with the prize, so swings and roundabouts. As a general rule, if you want to avoid engagements with other players, stick to missions further away from the safe-zones, or if you really don't want them at all, you can play on a PVE only server. The game is certainly challenging and engaging enough without fighting other players.

There is a roadmap of new updates coming, including the addition of a city for some urban warfare, new missions, more animals to increase the hunting component of the game, and at some point, wheeled vehicles. There will also be a tutorial added soon, which I can tell you will make the game a whole lot more approachable, as even after 30 hours I'm still working some of the game dynamics out. At the moment you need to watch some other people play on YouTube or Twitch.

Anyway, highly recommend the game and there's lots to look forward to in the future.

Update - 04/11/23

I've now passed 70 hours and still enjoying it!

Pick your poison:
• Deal with official servers that are lawless in every sense of the meaning but are subject to frequent server crashes lasting upwards of a week - while you have 7 days to log in until everything you build is wiped. (This is what killed 303).

Or 

• Play on private servers what you are subject to changing rules, admin abuse, weekly/monthly wipes, everyone runs just M99 or M4, and you can be banned at any point in time because you killed an admin before he could remove the stick from his rear. 

This game uses GPortal servers, that should be all you need to know. Dev's won't rollback 303 to restore bases that over half the server lost JUST after an update was released. I don't think they realize there's a fair chunk of players that only play on weekends (ya know, work, adult stuff), and because 303 and multiple other servers were down, and an update was released at the same time, people couldn't reset their aggressive 7-day timer and didn't get to try the new content. They loaded into a bare ground and not the base they worked on for weeks that was wiped without warning. 

I can't support this game anymore, even with almost 1,000 hours, they do the bare minimum to keep the community alive.

With almost 100 hours on the clock the game from the moment it launched till now it feels almost the same and what i mean is that the game feels clunky, the weapons are very inaccurate while moving even slightly around while the AI bots have the craziest aim I have ever seen. It lacks a lot of good survival mechanics from other games of its caliber even though the game is almost 3 years old and still is in (Early Access) which is a shame. the gameplay needs improvements the overall feel of the game feels weird from the shooting to the movement of the character I can't describe it with words. The performance is not well optimized having almost the same FPS from high settings to low settings and yes high settings punch my graphics card a bit but having medium to low settings and having the same FPS as high settings is a dead giveaway of a poorly optimized game. Also, the visibility of the game is ok you can't see the player models clearly from far distances it needs improvements even in this section as well. Overall the graphics are good the audio of the gun and environment are also strong new additions like the wolf are adding more in to the game but it needs more fixes. like the shooting to be more accurate while moving and reducing the weapon sway also a hotfix is needed for the enemy AI as well as the optimization and performance of the game.

Dead side right now still needs a lot of work in my opinion, with ai being able to see you when you cant see them, also with the addition of wolves that only live to annoy and don't give anything of use. Overall its a good game however with the current level of ai i find myself rage quitting a lot. But overall a good game with realistic guns.

No third person, no fast travel (there are clever ways to do that here, but you won't see it any year soon), no sleep/ rest or other expected survival mechanics. You can swim and walk through water, but you can't drink, or boil and drink? Too much time to set up for the game's content with it's clunky survival mechanics. Without proper 3rd person mechanics, even the 1st person ones fail.  If your bleeding money, or are looking for that prime Helvetia PvP; sure give it a go. But with other better developed titles....

I don't want to give this a bad review because I hope they keep working on it, It has everything to be a good game. 
Negatives:
Everyone is right about the running around ruining the game, it's terrible, but at the same time if they put in land vehicles everyone would just use them to run people over. They need to expand the train travel functionality and this game would be a 7/10 instead of a 5/10. At the very least add Add more fast travel by train locations around the map. Some real time train travel where maybe some enemies shoot at you along the way or make a mission where you hold up a train carrying some loot. Finding a place to build your base is a ludicrous process, and building it isn't much more satisfying. the jump mechanics HAVE to be improved because its currently useless and very annoying not being able to jump over a small ledge,rock, or fence. One of the worst things by far is the hunger and thirst aspect because the only way to really get anything most of the time is to buy it and its very expensive so you end up dying of hunger/thirst all the time and loose your stuff or at least have to run all the way back to it.

Positives:
Very fun combat. Bullets matter, gun selection and equipment is interesting and the playing field in that aspect is pretty level. Especially in PvE, you can take on some scavs that may have better weapons if you place your shots well. The randomized looting keeps things interesting. You can store a few things in the safe zone to help you rebuild if you lose everything. 

Missions would be better with friends because you can die pretty easy.

Deadside - Hardcore Survival at its Finest 💀🌲🔥

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5 Stars) - A relentless, hardcore survival experience

When it comes to survival games, Deadside takes it to a whole new level. This game is all about embracing the hardcore nature of the genre. It's not for the faint of heart, and it offers a level of intensity that's simply unmatched.

💀 Hardcore to the Bone - No Mercy 🔪🏚️
In Deadside, survival means fighting for every breath, every morsel of food, and every bullet. The game doesn't hold your hand; it throws you into a ruthless, post-apocalyptic world where danger lurks around every corner. The unforgiving nature of the game is what sets it apart, making every small victory feel like a monumental achievement.

🌲 An Open World of Desolation - Explore or Perish 🌍🪓
The game's open world is a stark, desolate wasteland filled with resources, but also with threats. Exploring it is a constant test of your survival skills. Whether you're scavenging for supplies, fending off hostile players, or hunting for your next meal, every moment is a struggle for existence.

🔥 Hardcore Community - Band Together or Betray 👥🪖
Deadside's hardcore nature is not just limited to the gameplay; it extends to the community as well. Here, players band together to form alliances and take on the challenges, but they're just as likely to betray each other for their own gain. Trust is a rare commodity in this world.

In a gaming landscape filled with survival titles, Deadside truly stands out as one of the most hardcore experiences you can find. It's a game that demands your full attention, your wits, and your survival instincts. If you're up for the challenge, it's an adventure you won't soon forget. 💀🪓🏚️👥🌲🔪🪖

This game needs vehicles to make it at all worth playing for more than a short amount of time. It needs them more than prone, more than boats, more than anything they have been working on in the last year or two. To the people saying it's harder than we think it is, it's certainly not so difficult that it takes several years to develop. There is a good game in here somewhere, but it becomes boring incredibly quickly because running around the map on foot is dreadful, and the players have been saying it for years. I cannot understand how they've ignored their Nolt feedback and update comments so completely. I have always wanted this game to progress and become popular, but I don't know that they deserve it at this point, and I don't know if it is recoverable. Sadly, the status of this game is in it's name. Honestly I know I will come back and reinstall it and give it another shot when vehicles are in the game, and I hope others will too, but I think too many players have uninstalled for good to ever make it a relevant title. While the devs' decisions have left me confused and annoyed, I still want them to succeed. I hope putting it on a big sale with the vehicle update can get people to play it, but with every month that passes the game becomes more outdated and irrelevant. At the pace these guys are going we will be driving cars in GTA6 before we do in Deadside.

I bought this game a couple days ago right after the 0.6.1.15129 patch. so far the game is amazing. i have more fun on here than i did back in the old days of day z arma 2 or even day z arma 3 servers even without the game being completely fleshed out. there is lots to do PvP is fun and the bots are fun to fight as well, sometimes they act almost like players but that said other times they just stand up and snap aim you so not sure why some act so different than others but hopefully they will continue to become more like players. there are lots of places to explore, military outposts to fight and you can fish, hunt ducks, drive boats run small missions and more. great little game with tonnes of potential, you can see that the devs have great plans for it and i only hope it continues to improve into the future.

Gives me "miscreated" vibes.
Fun gameplay loop with extra steps if you want.
Basically a battle royal/TDM, spawn in, find gear, look for action.
There are survival mechanics. thirst, hunger, and base building. all of which fit the game well without being clumsy or irritating. There are also objectives like missions and bunkers for high tier loot, base raids, and a large map littered with POI's.
But it all boils down to the same game play loop of spawn, loot, fight.
It's a good take on the dayz genre with less of a focus on survival and more of a focus on fighting. The AI being human also adds a nice change of pace over the normal zombies in games like this.

note game released in 2020 and due to world events the game has only really had 1 year of full development compared to dayz being released in 2013 and scum 2018.
but in the games current state its better then DayZ not up to the standard of SCUM. im playing this game to get a break from the 900 hours of scum and im actually enjoying it. having real NPC fight back randomly around the map is a nice welcome change to the zombies of scum and dayZ. and are actually threatening rather then an annoyance. because they shoot back you dont know if its players your in combat with or NPC till you kill one and the kill feed pops up in chat. the map is quite large  (currently half the size of scum) but currently only a 3rd of the map is available. with different POI and outpost containing NPC. 


however the game does fall short in areas: gun play is limited but okay. sounds are good, weapons look okay with limited attachments. basicly one scope or flash light fits all.  
at the moment the game is more walk and shoot simulator then survival. since your not stressing about food or water fighting Players or NPC is nice but the time between combat can get boring.

Sorry Devs but Scum will remain my go to open world survival. but deadside is a great game i am enjoying and excited for whats coming in the following updates. would recommend but would say to buy on offer due to the lack of current content.

Each update is another shovelful of dirt coming out of the grave itself. Starting solo is almost impossible.

The bot system is ridiculous. Imagine starting with a level 1 mission and the game spawns heavily armed bots around the mission location? Well, that's what happens. In other words, it's not enough to be forced to deal with the mission's bots, there are others around you to literally eat your ass with lots of sand and broken glass.

Other than that, if you are detected, the bots will relentlessly chase you for miles (that's if you don't get shot and die by a bot that appears to be cheating).

In addition to this concern, the hunger and thirst system is ridiculous, they fall very quickly. Buying basic survival items (water and food) is impossible by doing only level 1 missions, as the money received barely buys a can of food. Trying to get water from wells/cisterns is also impossible. Just now I passed by 3 villages and they were all deactivated. The developers just forgot that their game is in the style of a walking simulator, where you have to walk like a son of a bitch from one place to another.

This is all a great way to attract new players and even keep active ones. Congratulations on continuing to dig your own grave.

I understand that it's a game, it has to be fun and it also has to have a certain level of difficulty, but never impossible to play.

Game is better but still needs work. A lot of poi's are just frustrating/impossible to attempt altogether. You try and snipe them guess again same shit happens all of them just swarm you and you die. The only way you can beat missions is if you get lucky and find a spot they cant path find to and just take 1 out at a time over a few hours. I love this game but wtf man doing missions is such an frustrating process. Oh also their aim is still way to good over range i'l have bots hit me while spraying their aks from miles away doing half my fucking health with the best armor on. I can't begin to explain how frustrated i am with this bs. I spent an hour systematically trying to clear a lvl 3 mission dying 5 times during the whole process to a bot with an ak spraying me from miles away and when i finally killed enough of them to get anywhere close to this space the mission despawned. And that's not the first time its happened either. Would not recommend atm.

I've got 1500 hours and I can say, the game is no longer the pvp game it once was, devs are focused on the wrong things and take forever  to update the game, there lead community advisor for the game is a pve player who sucks at the game and cant pvp to save his life @loaf. There are only 2 servers populated at  any time (with exception of some weekend nights) and any above average gamer will be banned from private servers because they don't like competition (will say you're cheating and report  you to devs and when it comes back clean, they power-trip and ban for nonsensical reasons. server max is 50 and the ban list for certain servers exceeds that by 10 times ( no wonder servers don't fill up) official servers don't get over 10 pop so have fun playing a running simulator to find players that run away and the first sounds of gunfire. Players never start missions anymore like they used to, everyone plays so scared and only hides until you go to loot mission crate due to the fact that they updated game and completely destroyed the economy and rate at which you can find armors (the most valuable thing in game because it prevents one shots from mosins.) The map is wide open in most places and after 200m basically all the bushes you would consider as concealment arent even there for the guy camping with a one hit sniper way out. Who adds boats on a game that 98% land 2 % water, instead of cars or even bicycles. The game doesn't even have a TOS that should also tell you something. Bots have needed to be reworked since day 1, they run around a corner and instashoot you (doesnt show gun raise or nothing, just an instant snap and dead in less than .3 seconds. Bots can also shoot through bushes and grass even if they cant see you, which they have claimed to fix but as we all know they dont do anything right, and bots also can shoot while strafing back and forth never stopping and shoot with perfect accuracy at you, meanwhile you cant walk and shoot to save your life, you have to stop and as soon as you hit the hold breath key it forces you to run sometimes which take you out of aim and screws you into a death. I also cant  count the amount of times ive shot people and it not register(everyday occurance). Also dont let me forgot that if you go to the official deadside discord to make a dispute about someone they favor it results in a ban from discord. I feel the devs are so low that i wouldnt be surprised if i got banned from the game just for writing this review, they are tired of hearing about me anyway, i get reported to them on a daily occurrence for cheating when im clearly not. Maybe what the game needs is for devs to listen to people who actually put time into the game, instead of someone whose got a stick up their bum. they are all in one anothers pockets and its slowly and slowly killed the game and now here we are here with whats left, DEADside! I'm sure there are plenty of things ive forgot to mention on this rant as well!

***UPDATE**** Apparently the developers are scrapping the idea of removing the safezones for the official servers and are now saying that this will only affect community servers as an option, which is pretty much ok.

One community manager is claiming that this was never the idea and it was all due to a problem of poor reading from the people who became concerned with this terrible idea, but that's simply not true, or at the very best, was caused by really poor writting and communication with the community. There is no reason for them to even make such a big fuss about adding options to the community servers. All options for community servers they can add are welcome. Who would care? Even if they add really stupid, nonsensical or meme worthy changes, like for example, all players spawn as chickens and can only use their beaks as guns, the server owners could simply not use them and stick to the default settings. They don´t need to evaluate any feedback in that regard.

Also, It's written on the post that they wanted feedback on this because that would "...determine the outcome of development in this direction". Many discussion threads were made to talk about this, and a lot of negative feedback about safezone removal were posted, for weeks straight, and not a single peep from any of the devs or the mentioned community manager regarding this possible "misreading". Smells like a terrible damage control attempt, instead of just admitting that the idea was bad and was rejected. I advise that they seek improvements to the communication with the playerbase. Their forums are really small, so is the community, it won´t take any extra costs to actually pay more attention to the community forums.

If you like an expensive walking simulator, buy the game. If not, buy something else. Even drugs are better.

At current state, the game is bare bones. I advise waiting a year or two for more substantial updates.

You just do empty swings and do no damage.
You died? Well good luck, because there is no way to sneak your way to your corpse.
The game has small pay to win aspect, the supporter pack. x2 storage space, Compas and Binoculars.
So buy supporter pack and you get up above mentioned, hence the pay to win.

My biggest gripe at the moment is with Bot AI. As I said, very limited stealth system is currently in the game.
It definetly needs polishing and updating, that's why one of the reviews said "I'm more afraid of Bots than actual players." Because Bushes in forests don't obstruct AI bot sight, they SEE you ALWAYS.( When you enter their detection range) The only question they have in mind is, is there a solid object between you and them to prevent them from shooting.

Choice of Firearms is good enough, from what I've seen so far. But they could add a bit more. Have yet to find a proper sniper rifle. Current choices for buying are only 3, Hunter Rifle, and 2 Moksin variations. Which ain't much.
All in all, game has potential. And will give this game thumbs up when they update and polish it more.

"Deadside: Survive, Thrive, and Thrill in a Harsh Open World"

"Deadside," developed by Bad Pixel, is an open-world survival game that transports players to a post-apocalyptic wasteland. While it offers an intriguing premise and a blend of survival and shooter elements, the game struggles to rise above the competition in a genre filled with established titles.

Atmospheric Post-Apocalyptic World (3/5):
The game's post-apocalyptic setting is immersive, featuring desolate landscapes, abandoned structures, and an atmosphere of tension. The eerie silence broken by the occasional sound of gunfire or distant zombies adds depth to the environment.

Survival and Looting (3/5):
"Deadside" places a strong emphasis on survival mechanics, including hunger, thirst, and temperature management. Players must scavenge for resources, weapons, and gear to survive. The looting aspect of the game can be rewarding, as you uncover valuable items and weapons.

PvP and PvE (3/5):
The game offers a mix of PvP (Player vs. Player) and PvE (Player vs. Environment) gameplay. Engaging in firefights with other players or banding together to tackle AI-controlled zombies and creatures adds variety to the experience. However, the balance between these two aspects can sometimes feel uneven.

Crafting and Base Building (2/5):
While "Deadside" includes crafting and base-building mechanics, they are not as robust or intuitive as in other survival games. The limited building options and the complexity of the crafting system may frustrate some players.

Technical Issues (2/5):
"Deadside" has faced its share of technical issues, including bugs, server problems, and performance optimization challenges. These issues can detract from the overall gameplay experience.

Lack of Content (3/5):
One of the game's shortcomings is its lack of content, especially when compared to more established titles in the genre. The map, while reasonably sized, can feel limited over time, and the gameplay loop may become repetitive.

Community and Development (3/5):
The game has an active community and a development team that continues to work on updates and improvements. However, the pace of development progress and addressing player feedback can vary.

Conclusion:
"Deadside" offers an intriguing premise with its post-apocalyptic survival setting and a blend of PvP and PvE gameplay. However, it faces stiff competition in the survival genre, and while it has potential, it struggles to stand out due to technical issues, limited content, and less polished mechanics. If you're a dedicated fan of the survival genre and enjoy the thrill of scavenging and engaging with other players in a harsh world, "Deadside" may offer some entertainment. Still, it may not fully satisfy players looking for a more refined and content-rich survival experience.

I bought the game and all the DLC,s and all I have to say is this game is not very single user friendly, not everyone has a bunch of friends to play, I played for 61 hrs single and it could be so great but even the easy missions is very difficult for a beginner when you start out with nothing and trying to find a decent weapon and a backpack to carry items is hard when an enemy shoots at you and you die with like one hit and lose everything and have to start over because your corpse is only available for a few minutes to get your stuff back but you also have about a  5-10 minute time limit to respawn back so you have to pick the closest area and by the time you get back to your corpse to retrieve your stuff it's gone, and finding anything of use is not happening unless you can take on the hard and epic missions or buy it, and everything costs so much money and you get very little in return when selling items at the shops it took me forever to save up enough money to buy a backpack with 15 slots and a good weapon just to have it all taken away when I was looting some houses and out of nowhere a caravan mission popup near me I had no chance of surviving, I was killed 2 times trying to sneak in and get my stuff back and then my corpse just disappeared with all the stuff I worked so hard to get and after 61 hrs of playing I have to start over with nothing worth using, and building a base so you can keep extra items in sucks, you need nails and wood, the wood part is easy just chop a  tree to get wood but the nails you either have to buy them which is very expensive or try to find them when looting out of the 61 hrs of play I maybe found about 40 nails, so I only had 4 floors and building a chest to store items takes finding sheet metal, I could not find it anywhere it was very very rare when I did find it so I only had 2 chests, I'm not going to recommend this game for single player, but since its early access hopefully it can get better for the single player until then Not Recommended.

Here are some Tips If you like to play

1. Get a Gun ASAP
2. Get a Bottle and some Food / Drinks
(You can find these thing in houses like in Battle royal game)
3. Get some Cloths (Try to get the cloths that give you more inventory slot)
4. Tear up some Extra clothing and get Rags
5. Find some Alcohol, Moonshine, Vodka and then you can craft some healing patch.
6. Then Try to do easy mission on the map

Enjoy!

I'm giving it a Yes because there's too much negativity in this world but hear me out.

If you played Rust, Dayz, Tarkov, you can find similarities, big ones, in many areas of the game.

Now, the team is small, the game looks good, but it's janky as all hell on basically every aspect. A lot of polish is required on pretty much everything.

Considering they're better off adding new things rather than rewrite their current content, take into account the slow dev process, and you end up with a potential fun game that could be so much better.

The issue is, most likely, the new stuff they work on is suffering from the current state of the game.

I didn't PvP at all yet, but otherwise it's still entertaining for now.

The game isnt bad. I love being able to go in and out of third person to first person. I enjoy that the shooting is difficult and gives me pubg feels with the same feeling rust gives you from trying to survive and improve. That feeling quickly fades away when you realize that you have to walk for miles because the devs thought it was a good idea to add boats before land vehicles when most of the traveling is on land. When food is scarce and theres no animals there to kill and add to the realism of the landscape. You cant just approach a river and fill the flask with water?... The lack of these things kills my ability to get immersed completely into the game which i was hoping for. If they took the best things from pubg,Day Z, and Rust and left out the bad this game would be amazing. One thing i will say is good is the raid conditions they set. Must kill owner and get a Raid Token to raid his base and you only have an hour. Very Creative and streamlined so you dont have to give away your life to enjoy the game. If the map was bigger more people on the server and all these issues were fixed with hard and enjoyable missions filled with difficult bots all while having real people trying to kill you this game would be phenomenal.

A lot of potential in this game. If they could manage to sort out the bugs that cause you to randomly lose all your hard won gear, and go back to making it better with each update rather than making it worse it could be great. It is like a less punishing Day Z in some ways. a large map, an annoying "tamagotchi" element where you have to find scarce food and water(thankfully you don't need to consider keeping warm and dry). Long periods of downtime punctuated by intense action. The AI are a little too accurate at times and can hit you through trees i.e. when they are invisible to you, but when it's good the gunfights can be great. Cannot recommend in it's current state.

VOIP, crafting, survival, loot of several different kinds, and tons of fps fun make for a great game. It's a kinder format than most survival looters, but has some extremely challenging elements that make it easy to dial in the level of difficulty simply by avoiding or engaging with danger. The ability to craft and talk via VOIP also make for some interesting interactions, such as when you build a trading post and have randoms come help even while being in an extremely dangerous PvP server. Sharing a campfire and enjoying a peaceful moment was not what I expected at all, but made for a great memory.

Nah fuck these guys. the very first problem was buying it when it first came out on steam. decent idea lots of potential. but it actually felt and played a lot like every single survival shooter out there rn. says its a HARDCORE SHOOTER but all i got was hard shooter. the AI is CRACKED. or ass. no in between. you can cheese them. or you'll get one tapped. again no in between. they advertise base building and raiding but the chances of you doing it are so slim its worthless. especially when you realize you there are only 2 backpacks that can carry guns... so whats the point of raiding a base???? so i can get 2 guns and come back to more people at the base. fun. how about the actual player base. oh boy the player base is literally dead. its not there and when it is its useless. the armor system makes no sense. base building is and tedious and useless. the gun scaling doesn't make any sense to me. it seemed to me that the cheap ass AKS 74 seemed to serve me better than any other gun i touched smh. they dont listen to the majority of the community either. the other reason most people quit was because we were lied to then everything was changed then when we saw change we were ignored and left to rot. then they decided boats FUCKING BOATS were better than a car system, map expansion, AI rework,s and gun play... we complained.. we were ignored... we deserved better.

Starting out is too much of a pain. If you're a masochist, sure, you can get used to it and eventually do well. For me, I am tired of sneaking into a settlement to find SOMETHING to shoot with, only for the AI to magic their way to finding out I am there before sending waves of killers my way while I try to kill them all between reloads with a wimpy 9mm pistol. If you are one of those gods out there who never miss a headshot, I guess you'll probably be ok. If you're only human, you get to suffer. Sneaking back in to get your stuff usually results in an even larger group of AI bots coming for you, and then you get the 10 minute respawn timer on that town. I thought I had cleared a town, only for another small army to show up.

I'm tired of playing games for people who hate themselves. Tone down the number and omniscience of bots in starting towns. Everyone may not agree with me, and that's fine, but this game is not for everyone, and maybe not for most of us. It could be good eventually, but right now DayZ is the much better choice.

Proceeds to mow us down and then stand on our loot forever so it was almost impossible to get it back but by the time we did it didn't matter cause i felt defeated. Overall 8/10 would play again

Overall very good game, I'd say the survival mechanics are less forgiving than Rust, but not anything too cumbersome. There's always something to do. I like the concept of the safezone storage so you don't have to build a base right away, which gives casual gamers a good outlet. I will say I like everything about the game, the gunplay, missions, etc, but there are 3 things to keep in mind:

1. Servers usually only have 10 to 35 people, even during peak hours. I mostly play PvE, so that's not really a downside, hbut just keep in mind.

2. Enemies are hard to spot from a distance (200m+). Even with antialiasing all the way up, High graphics, the bots can be hard to spot.

3. We need something like a horse or vehicle to get around the map. It's pretty sizeable so I use the autosprint function. We just need more ways to get around.

Other than that, great game.

If you like DayZ you'll love this game!! You can play PVP or PVE but fair warning there will be NPCs that try to kill you on both!!

Great Concept but is it fun... No. I guess if you like sitting in corners for hours not playing the game that you paid money for to shoot some poor soul in the face. If you get satisfaction out of that somehow than cool but for people that like to play the game we payed for, not for us. What they mean when they say it's a hardcore survival game is that your footsteps can be heard a mile a way and full squads will be crouched in bushes to kill you and take the knife you spawn with. There is no goal, the "events" are just AI with guns. Even if you manage to take them out and get all the sweet loot without someone third partying you and taking all the loot that you got from killing all the AI what do you do with it? Go kill more AI or sit in corners and use them on other players. There is no point to this game. Just a big empty map with assets, AI, and the poor souls that spend their time in it. It's sad because the gun play could be good if they wanted to make a realistic shooter or something like Battlefield or Tarkov.

It's getting better!

But, now with quite a few hours in the game... honestly, it's potential ridden Trash. 

Potential is outstanding.  Unfortunately NPC's are ridiculously difficult to deal with.   I know, I know "....used to be hard, but now I roll right through them".   Good for you.  Most of the rest of us aren't blessed with lightening fast reflexes, you know, to deal with that NPC you know is just around the corner, you're aiming in the space he's about to occupy, and still he manages to get around the corner and headshot you with a long rifle that is literally longer than the space between the two of you.

OR, the eyesight to be able to see with laser-beam-clarity through weeds and brush, or deal with the insta-shots you get when you fire.  They literally know where you are and have you crosshaired before you even think about pulling the trigger (and naturally, Heli's seldome offer 0 cover in the immediate area.

Or... well, lets just say they're faster than a terrified Navy Seal running downhill with a tailwind on grease.  Nobody in history is that fast guys.  Nobody.

Guys, "Potential".  It's good when it's difficult.  It's spectacularly bad when you up the difficulty and compensate with a 600m run back to your body.

It's kind of stupid right now folks.

I have sunk many an Hour into Deadside in a short amount of Time and my issues seem to line up with most of the community:
Bots: Super soldiers with X-ray who will either turn any number of degrees and one tap you in any armor and will chase you to the ends of the earth, abusing terrain hitbox that you cant see to murder you before you have a chance to even think you have a chance.
Playerbase: yeah theyre toxic but its a hardcore pvp(ve) survival. Its to be expected
Bases: Very barebones. Buggy. but a fun and actually relaxing timesink....Just Press Y when smacking the tree for 20 minutes. Most servers dont allow players to base camp, but are ok with people camping outside of your base so be warned.
My BIGGEST complaints are:
Being able to just Destroy any guns they loot or find. including yours. If they kill you and cant carry it, they just break it down so neither can you. And there is NO requirements needed to do so. Just your Bare hands.
Night Time Nvidia Filters: Just remove night mode. Too many people exploit the filters and can see you cross map with the damn thing that nightmode has absolutely no purpose other than to punish new players.
 +They added boats so i can deafen myself and move much faster across the map
Its addicting though so I reccomend

Decent game, however in my opinion the gunplay is very dated. Weapon movement and animations feel very clunky, and there is only like 3 different scopes in the game which all feel very awkward and have bad sight pictures. When compared to games like DayZ or Rust the gunplay is just not even close so as of now I cant recommend this game.

Game is been in development for 3 years and in terms of content they've added so far well its totally lacking and hopefully they do change that and actually release massive updates later on. There's a lot of flaws left and right but its more playable compare to other post-apocalyptic games. It is like rust minus the silly designs and dayz with no zombies, cars and heli's. 

Most people exaggerate the AI's aimbot if anything it's more of a they do more damage than your average enemy AI's. But if you play long enough you'll learn some advantages that you can use to manipulate the AI's reaction. PvP is kinda dead but PvE is fun as long as they add more updates to it. 

If devs are reading this add factions and different type of enemies(They're not gonna add zombies). Or just add steam workshop mod support tbh. I wouldn't say it's a good buy but compare to other survival early access games I have played that cost a bit more even through discount, I totally enjoyed this one and even bought the supporter pack later on. Try it out for under 2 hours and if it's not your cup of tea just refund it.

I had a review here before editing this one. 

After playing.... I am disappointed I wasted money on this game. 


1.) My arms are jello. In what survival shooter game does my hip fire AND ADS CONSTANTLY jiggle. NONE. This is my number 1 issue and until it is fixed I will not be playing more. There are multiple games out on the market that have a better gun play system than this. All they seem to care about so far is updating boats and cucking you on survival elements like how much resources are given when consuming items.

2) Base building is atrocious. Doesn't want to work correctly or intended 99% of the time, not even half  the time MOST of the time. Then after countless wipes you are expected to go through the pain staking process again. This is just so bad on gameplay, need 1000 nails for a decent base that will get wiped within 2 months for you to need to do it again all while struggling to even get the wall or floor you want to place down. 

3.) WE NEED MORE CONTENT. No I don't mean I want another boat to ride in? WHO CARES. Give me a land vehicle if you are going to leave every "city" (the cities are like 1 block of a normal city) 2km apart I need a reason to play besides a running simulator. 

MESSAGE TO DEVS: You have essentially taken DayZ... and made it DayZ without zombies... no one wants a cut and copy unoriginal idea, get some balls and start making decisions that go against the flow of your normal every day in russia shooter. Its over done. Your game will die within the next year if you don't start making some changes. Especially to your atrocious gun play that acts like I handed a 2 year a fully loaded RPG and expect them to hold it steady. No reason to have my cross hair, red dot, acog what have you on the enemy and STILL miss a shot. Really disappointed in this and the changes that have and haven't been made.

Go buy SCUM, Escape from Tarkov, shit even by DayZ but don't waste your time on a game that the gun play feels like you cant even shoot a fucking side of the barn with a howitzer.

If you are here for the base building, than you are better off going to minecraft or dayz, since those games give you the freedom to build anywhere. In Deadside you have to build a land claim, which only lets you build in one small area. This doesn't sound bad, right? Well guess what, you can not build within 150 to 200m from a road, base, settlement, or any other type of building. I spent 2 hours running around trying to find a place to put down a land claim and when I did, I was not only 2km away from anything but my claim glitched out and disappeared. Just wait until you hear news on improvements to building before you buy this.

The unimaginable has happend.

Imagine yourself, walking through the swamp, when suddenly, a duck flies out of the reeds, loudly quacking. Yes my friends, it's duckhunt 3d, with many hunting locations, weapons and the classic duck sounds you might remember from the NES classic.

To flesh it out they've added a decent survival games which fixes my many grievances with other survival games (scum/dayz) You have a storage at the 2 savezones, so you don't have to build a base right away. You can find weapons nearly everywhere, making it a lot less likely you'll die 10 times before even finding a way to defend youself. And missions give people something else to do then just kill eachother, so people here not only shoot you, but often engage in convo and ask you team up. Last, but certainly not least, you can't be raided anytime, removing the constant coming online and finding your base raided that other games have.

The whole vibe is a lot more  friendly and less frustrating.

It ain't all good though. The game clearly needs more content, the npc enemy's need a serious ai tweaking, and there's a dozen other little things to need to be added and fixed. Basicly like all survival games
big fun time

Fun PVP survival game. There's a million survival games out there but this is definitely one of the better ones. Its easy to get started and find a weapon and gear. It has its hardcore elements but it's also pretty casual, meaning you don't have to grind for hours and hours to get anywhere like other survival games. Graphics are great and it runs surprisingly well, never really dip below 140fps on ultra.

My only big complaint is that the enemy AI is very very verrrry stupid. It's like the absolute bare minimum pve AI can be. If you spot a group of them and shoot, they all immediately turn and lock onto you and shoot. They don't take cover or flank or anything like that, they simply just walk straight towards you while shooting until you either kill them or they kill you. Playing solo and running into a big group of them in a small space can be terrifying as you eventually have to reload or bandage yourself while there's 8 enemies walking in a single file line like morons straight towards you. Seriously, they make scavs in Tarkov seem smart. 

But yeah besides that, its good fun.

Amazing game!

In a way this is Turbo DayZ. It is an open world survival looter/shooter. Has base building etc. But unlike Dayz you can find a weapon and ammo and other gear in about 15 minutes and not 6 hours. The graphics are very well done and performance is solid. The developers continue to work on the game and keep adding cool new features. Recently adding boats, duck hunting, fishing, new towns and more. Once they add some sort of ground vehicle like loud dirt bikes or 4 wheeler's the game should be great.

Ok, this game can be fun, and when I first started playing it, this was much more fun. I remember being able to take on the npcs solo, as long as I moved around a lot and kept trying to misdirect them. This game used to be a lot of fun with a group and also solo, the AI was difficult but not impossible. After buying this game when it first came out (and purchasing the developer support pack), I have a different opinion now. I just tried to play it the last few days with my buddy, and we kept getting lazer beamed by the AI. I used to be able to hide behind rocks and trees to try to survive (not always successfully mind you), and as long as I could run far enough, the AI didn't one tap me the second they see me... I am disappointed in the direction this game has gone in, I always held it in high regard, but after trying to play for the last week with my buddy (who I told to purchase the game to play it with me), I am upset. We are literally being one/two shot by NPC's and it sucks. We used to be able to survive, and actually kill them, but now we try and capture different events and we get shot at before we can even see where they are located. In the current state, it is a waste of time. Maybe, there is a hardcore player base that has over 1000 hours in this game that knows how to progress, but unfortunately, it's not me. This game is not worth even 100 hours. At this point in the game, I am very upset with the difficulty of the NPC's, and I don't think I will be playing it again at it's current state. I am at 66 hours (around 55ish hours before playing in the current state), and I realize that isn't much, but at this point, I regret buying the game. What happened? If I wanted to grind, I would have played a tony hawk pro skater game... The game used to be much better after you found a scope for your gun. Now a scope on your gun doesn't mean anything, because the second you sight an NPC at an event worth looting, they can shoot your face with iron sights. Enjoy re-spawning and trying to get back to your loot... That's the new meta in this game

AS MUCH as people say this is a baby of dayz, rust, tarkov, ect...
Deadside is its own thing.
If you have any interest in these games I listed, and you are looking for something new to put time in and enjoy. This is it.

At its core, its really just a fun open world shooter, unfortunately its highly lacking in depth and has a lot of jankiness. The gun play feels solid. The basebuilding is a glitchy nightmare. You have to crouch spam and spam f to place boxes in your base. When servers restart it resets all vehicles in the world. It seems the only vehicles in the world are boats, making transport a bit of a hassle. I still havent figured out how to get branches even after googling it and ended up having to spawn them in. The game also def does not hold your hand and gives very little explanation as to what everything is/does. The pricing of items for selling doesnt make much sense, a soda goes for 6k from trader to player but a pistol from player to trader can be less than 200

I still think this game is worth it if on sale and you already have some buds willing to play it, otherwise solo just gets boring very quickly.
Aside from the aimbotting AIs it all g
DayZ with more PVP

Only really worth it on sale. You'll hit the peak of content in under 20 hours and after that there's a wall.

PVP isn't rewarding when enemies you've killed are able to immediately respawn at a nearby town and be back in under 5 minutes to grub a gun off a bot's body and kill you before you've can finished looting and healing. The gunplay does feel good, and it's pretty easy to go out and get some serviceable gear if you lose a kit. 

PVE is dull at it's peak, and rewards don't match the inputs at the highest level missions/events. Not to mention, out of the maybe 20 wells on the map, you'll be lucky to have 2 that have water? 

Basebuilding is shallow and haphazardly put together, it feels like building a house with toothpicks and elmers glue & all it really ends up being is a place you can throw stuff in containers and refill your water with the single water collector per base.  

TLDR: Get it if it's on sale like I did, play it for a weekend & maybe come back in 3 more years when they've added a few more towns, a few more guns and maybe something slightly more interesting to do.

This game definitley isn't complete it's lagging at times. It also can be a bit awkward in the beginning, but this has a lot and I mean a lot of potential to be the greatest game alive. In my opinion it takes the world of Day Z, the fighting experience of Tarkov (with the weapons mechanics and scavs), and the base building and safe zones of Rust. I basically only play Survival or Military games. 2 years ago I bought Deadside and refunded it, I recently repurchased the game.

As a big DayZ fan (439 hours since 2020) I wasn't expecting this game to reinvent the wheel but give me a more rounded version of the experience I was used to, and it did exactly that. Deadside is very clearly a love letter to DayZ and games like DayZ but it's smooth, optimized nicely and is essentially like if DayZ SA was its own standalone product. 

The main difference is everything is faster. The map is smaller, the loot is easier to find etc. which makes the game so fun to play. Unlike SCUM where you can go hours without seeing any loot or any sign of intelligent life, Deadside's AI is abundant just enough so you never really feel relaxed. That's not to say DS is better than DayZ or SCUM, but while similar theres an entirely different approach that doesn't rely on you having to log in daily and play for hours at a time.

For $12 it's hard to beat, and I highly recommend to anyone looking for a nice survival switch up.

Not great.. it's pretty empty as far as content goes. The building is pretty crappy and not intuitive. It's like they took DayZ and got rid of the majority of the content, scrapped it down to the bare bones, and then re-skinned it. They have AI enemies with guns, but the AI can see through everything and spot you immediately. They have issues traversing the terrain to get to you if you go into a building. Any AI that is better than an "easy" level will kill you in two or three shots and that can happen in a second. Loot re-spawns within seconds, so there's no challenge there. I wouldn't recommend getting this until they expand on it a LOT.

ERKEN ERİŞİM İNCELEMESİ
There is less than 700 people on this game usually at any given time. Yeah ok its classed as a "HARDCORE MULTIPLAYER SHOOTER" so I know that throws a lot of players off but I mean, you should see how bad the game actually is.

What I have experienced and how I feel
⚫You can craft a base, awesome - Think rust but lifeless. Pointless. It gets torn down before you actually get to build it.
⚫The development speed is glacial. I am not kidding. You will be waiting 2 years for a fix for a bug that hundreds of players are complaining about.
⚫The "small" amount of players on this game are TOXIC as all hell and do NOT let you play the game. If I want this I'd go play rust as it is more alive and BASICALLY THE SAME THING.
⚫They called it a "realistic game with survival elements" but it needs more animals to hunt. Some for of weather such as RAIN. Yes thats correct. Maybe add some form of sickness to give some use to pills... and definitely work on more base build features as its so barebones.
⚫I think PvP should be restricted in sections across the map, for obvious toxic reasons.(referring to how toxic the game is)
⚫It can be played in PVE and PVP, okay.... this one is a lie. Its PVEVP so the devs are selling a FALSELY advertised game in my opinion. Not once can you choose to just go and PVE. If you can, well... im an idiot and never seen that option.
⚫It has "Realistic weapons".... okay. Trust me... they are hardly "realistic" compared to Escape from Tarkov or Arma.
You can craft your own stuff... hahahahahahhaaha... funny.
⚫The animations are lacklustre at best. When you "open a can of energy" to drink you legit just hear it open and then you hold the can in front of you with your arms stretched out. Cans not even open either. This one makes me laugh as it looks like you are sh***ing yourself.
⚫The games community is a hotspot for toxicity and it drives most new players away. I once was running around a map and just seeing what "high level" players were doing to a new player disgusted me. Me and a friend had to get our good weapons on to kill the 4 man group harassing a fresh spawn. After we had killed them, we got comments on our steam accounts with... lets just say "toxicity" and end it there.

My Verdict
All of this combined, I can say this game has been dead in the water since day one. I bought it day one, played it a little and then played it on another steam account as I refunded it. I have 657 hours in this game in total and I have not seen any improvement to it at all. If anything it feels like it has ♥♥♥♥♥♥ worse. The game feels hollow and it really does not feel like theres much to do in it. The price is decent enough at least for £16.75 but thats about it.

The game was reported to be similar to dayZ. Well I could say that it was but that would be a lie. Graphically it is far superior to DayZ. The ai patrols and missions are quite fun, I have heard people say the AI is broken and the missions such as convoy are not doable...well that is simply not true....this isn't Halo. You cant just charge in and expect to survive. pro tip. Use a  30cal or larger rifle such as the Mosin or Dragunov... hit them from a base distance of 300m. ..thin them out..then switch to an m4 with iron sights or a cqb holographic sight. Stay crouched to cut down noise...the Ai can hear you run and will react.... Peek your corners...and check your aim. I solo hard missions and convoy all the time.   

They just released the 2023 road map and they are planning on adding a lot more features this year. I am frankly excited to see how it plays out. I have over 1000 hours in Dayz on vanilla and heavily modded servers...and I walked away to play deadside... and I can honestly say I have no problem not looking back. However I would like more lore to be added to explain the situation and backdrop of the situation you as the player find yourself in. In most every way Deadside is superior to dayz.... the Ai is great and helps keep it immersive....no more zombies thank god....am soooo sick of zombie games. Wouldnt mind some rescue missions..... bailing out players that get in way over their heads doesn't count lol...thats every night for me. If you are thinking about buying..... do it. You won't regret it. PvP is always toxic.... its pvp. However most of the PVE servers are filled with some real good people. IF you still find it toxic.... then maybe its you and they are just getting retribution on you for some toxic crap you have done. The overall community is amazing.

Although this game needs a lot of polishing / optimizing it is fun and may fill that void while waiting for the next DayZ update. I bought the game cheap while it was on sale and have no regrets... Remember "Duke Nukem Forever" worst five dollars spent on a game that had taken 13 years to make. 

I see a lot of comments saying the players are "Toxic" and have yet to experience any at all on PvE servers, most of the player base I interacted with helped a lot of new people in the game including myself so that the community will grow.
With that said I have yet to delve into the PvP side of it and have no knowledge of how toxic it is... I imagine it is no better or worse compared to DayZ PvP on official servers that normally has large groups controlling the map with alt accounts everywhere.

This game is not a DayZ, SCUM, Rust, Tarkov killer and probably never will be... The game is enjoyable PvE wise if you just want to do the events, missions and dodging the shots from NPCs.

Also if you are having issues with Direct X11 no idea if the game still has any, use -d3d12 for the games launch command on steam and it might help with some of the performance issues if any exist.

Title: Deadside Review: An Atmospheric Survival Experience

Rating: 4/5

Deadside is an open-world survival game developed by Bad Pixel. Set in a post-apocalyptic world, the game offers a tense and atmospheric experience where players must navigate dangerous environments, scavenge for resources, and engage in both PvE and PvP combat.

One of the standout features of Deadside is its immersive atmosphere. The game effectively captures the desolate and gritty nature of its post-apocalyptic setting, with detailed environments, abandoned structures, and hauntingly beautiful landscapes. The sound design adds to the immersion, enhancing the feeling of tension and danger as you explore the world.

The survival mechanics in Deadside are well-implemented. Players need to manage their hunger, thirst, and health while also keeping an eye on their ammunition and equipment durability. Finding and utilizing resources becomes crucial, as it directly impacts your chances of survival. The game strikes a good balance between being challenging and rewarding, providing a sense of accomplishment when you successfully overcome the harsh conditions.

Combat in Deadside is intense and unforgiving. Whether you're facing off against AI-controlled enemies or engaging in PvP encounters with other players, every encounter feels dangerous and impactful. The gunplay mechanics are solid, offering a satisfying sense of weight and impact. The addition of stealth elements adds an extra layer of strategy to engagements, allowing players to choose between going in guns blazing or opting for a more covert approach.

The open-world aspect of Deadside provides a vast playground for exploration. There are different regions to discover, each with its own distinct environments and threats. The game world is filled with various landmarks, lootable areas, and hidden secrets, encouraging players to venture off the beaten path. Additionally, the inclusion of vehicles adds mobility and allows for faster traversal across the map.

While Deadside offers an enjoyable survival experience, it's not without its flaws. The game can feel somewhat repetitive at times, as the objectives and activities tend to follow a similar pattern. More variety in missions and tasks would have added depth to the gameplay. Additionally, the AI could be more refined, as enemy behavior can be predictable and lacks diversity.

Overall, Deadside delivers an engaging and atmospheric survival experience. With its immersive world, solid survival mechanics, and intense combat, it keeps players on their toes and provides a thrilling post-apocalyptic adventure. Despite some minor shortcomings, Deadside is a game worth exploring for fans of the survival genre.

I've owned the game for a while and check back in every few months to see whats what. This time around (June 2023) I'm having a good time. I prefer PVE so that's what I'm basing my comments off of.

Gunplay feels great as always and the couple improvements they did recently help a lot with quality of life. While I wish we had land vehicles over boats, I'm glad we have some way of traveling around the map versus running. I really want this game to succeed, but I feel like the sparse nature of the map between landmarks on the map is what hurts it the most. Occasionally you'll find a roaming patrol of NPCs or a run down village, but not much else. I'm not sure what they could do to improve the gameplay between running to missions, but I hope they have something planned. 

All that aside, it's really a fun/challenging game when you're in the action. Just wish there was a little more to do between the action. I still recommend it. It runs great with few bugs or issues that I have run into. Give it a shot especially if you got some friends to join you.

Deadside at this point in time has not one enjoyable feature. Between the AI of the enemy bots that are unrealistically accurate and at the same time terribly inaccurate at close range, the extremely long healing animation to only heal 5hp with a singular rag, gun play that is not only unrealistic, but also extremely basic (no bullet impacts to be able to tell where your shots land at any range outside of about 30 meters), the inventory and looting system being very bare bones and unpolished, water and food stats (quickly running out of water with hardly any consistent ways to be able to re hydrate, besides only being able to build your own well to collect water, or a random well in the open world, which never have water, and there isn't any water wells at the safe zones, and the VERY rare occasion that water/soda spawns as loot, or you can spend $6000 at a vendor for just ONE can of soda that only refills 10 hydration, they only used to cost $175-$350 each). The whole gameplay loop entirely revolves around travelling to spots on the map to complete different objectives that change in difficulty (which is just the level of aimbot accuracy the AI possess, plus the weapons they use, even though an AI with a pistol seems to do as much damage as a AI with a shotgun, sniper, or MG), you go to one of these objectives, kill enemies, loot them and the reward chest, then rinse and repeat. There is base building, but since supplies like sheet metal are completely random, that isn't even a viable way to play. Deadside is just a poorly built shooter with mechanics that are on as basic of a level as the original DOOM, with survival mechanics thrown in, that only make the experience more tedious and downright boring. 

Definitely not worth the current or sale price and I would still not recommend Deadside to anyone even if it went free to play, without the game having major overhauls and improvements across the board.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

[h1] This Tarkov and 7 Days to Die Player says "No" to Deadside...for now [/h1]

I'm a fan of the survival genre and have been playing these types of games for some time. My buddy who plays these games with me wanted to give Deadside a try since it was on sale, so we took the plunge.

Initially, we were having a good time learning the game. Loot seemed readily available, NPC fighting encounters were fun, and gun mechanics seemed alright. Where we started running into issues was our hydration meter.

Food/hydration doesn't seem to deplete at an unreasonable rate, but finding liquids was incredibly annoying. Since we were fresh on the scene, we weren't knowledgeable about the various ways to gather water/liquids.

We would occasionally find a soda on an NPC we whacked, but we weren't finding these fast enough to keep up our hydration. And we were doing a whole bunch of killing. So we made our way to a safe zone. To our surprise, a single soda cost $6.9k. This just didn't seem right. The Deadside wiki said sodas cost $350 each, and I couldn't find any other documentation online to indicate why the price was so inflated.

So I thought, maybe this was a server specific setting that jacked the econ way up. So I loaded into another server and ran to a safe zone to compare prices. Same coal-raking deal there - $6.9k for a single soda that barely scratches the surface of your hydration needs.

I made a post on Reddit posing the question regarding pricing. Several people responded "just go to a well with a canteen" while dodging the question of why was a price that was originally set at $350 jacked to $6.9k like this was post WWI Germany.

As I'm told, this was to "make purchasing survival items a non-viable strategy." My question to that is - then why bother having this item available to buy at all in game?

Prior to this knowledge of being able to gather water at wells, I was forced to but 1 soda, which ended in me selling 3 guns, several pieces of clothing, all my "junk" items, and all the loose cash I found. For 1 soda.

Look - I understand in a survival game you don't want folks to be able to just farm cash to meet all their needs. That's fair. But to give no explanation to new players on some of the core mechanics of the game whilst bending them over backwards for something as simple as a soda that barely puts a dent in my hydration needs seems incredibly shortsighted. I like survival games, but none have been as annoying as Deadside in figuring out what the hell you need to do to survive.

This got me looking closer into the dev support for this game. I've seen numerous complaints that fixes/enhancements come at a slow pace. This coupled with my initial frustrations of the game has lead me to believe a lot of folks won't enjoy the game in its current state. If devs start adding in more features in the future and take in some player feedback, I could see myself coming back. For now, I'll stick to my $2 sodies at 7-11.

Deadside, an open-world survival game, has captivated me like no other. From the moment I stepped foot into its vast and treacherous world, I was hooked. The game offers an adrenaline-fueled experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat, constantly craving more. Deadside excels in several aspects, and it's my pleasure to share my thoughts on this exceptional game.

First and foremost, the gameplay in Deadside is simply phenomenal. The developers have managed to strike the perfect balance between challenge and reward, creating a survival experience that is both exciting and addictive. The world feels alive, with every encounter presenting a unique opportunity for triumph or defeat. Whether it's scavenging for resources, engaging in intense firefights with other players, or navigating through the hostile environment, Deadside ensures that no two moments are ever the same.

One of the standout features of Deadside is its attention to detail. The game's graphics are stunning, immersing players in a beautifully crafted post-apocalyptic landscape. From dilapidated buildings to dense forests and eerie swamps, every location feels distinct and believable. The sound design is equally impressive, with atmospheric audio cues that enhance the overall experience. It's these small but essential details that make Deadside feel like a living, breathing world.

Another aspect that sets Deadside apart is its robust multiplayer component. Whether you choose to cooperate with other survivors or embrace a more cutthroat playstyle, the interactions with other players add an exhilarating layer of unpredictability. The thrill of forming alliances, engaging in intense firefights, or betraying your temporary allies for personal gain is unparalleled. Deadside's multiplayer offers endless possibilities for emergent gameplay, ensuring that no two sessions are ever alike.

Furthermore, Deadside boasts a comprehensive progression system that rewards both skill and perseverance. As you explore the world and complete objectives, you'll unlock new weapons, gear, and abilities, allowing for more creative approaches to survival. This sense of progression keeps you invested in the game, constantly striving to become more formidable in the face of ever-present dangers.

Lastly, the developers of Deadside have shown a commendable commitment to ongoing updates and community engagement. They actively listen to player feedback, constantly refining and expanding the game to ensure a rewarding experience for all. This dedication to improvement is evident in the regular content updates and bug fixes, which showcase the developers' passion for their creation.

In conclusion, Deadside is an outstanding survival game that has captured my attention and held it firmly from start to finish. Its engaging gameplay, stunning graphics, immersive world, and robust multiplayer make it a must-play for fans of the genre. If you're seeking an intense and unpredictable survival experience that will keep you coming back for more, then Deadside is the game for you. Prepare to test your skills, forge alliances, and fight tooth and nail for survival in this exceptional post-apocalyptic adventure.

They should dial the scavs back because it is very annoying to clear hard missions and above as a group and as a solo it is a task best left to people with a lot more hours in the game than I have.

The scavs seem like they either totally miss, or instant kill. It is not very often that you feel yourself just get tagged once or twice by a scav spray. I have seen 3 of them miss every shot of full spray for 2-3 seconds, and I have seen one scav hit the nastiest spray transfer of all time and absolutely dumpster my duo and I. 

The pvp is actually fantastic. The healing mechanics are simple and while I find the dehydration mechanics (when usining the higher tier, faster healing meds) annoying, at least there are methods of fast healing in the game. This makes solo v duo or even solo v trio possible without ratting. 

Short version, the PvP is fun but the PvE is tedious. The game is challenging and unforgiving for all the wrong reasons. The scavs randomly have better aim than any player at times and it is frustrating to say the least. The scavs should have a more consistent accuracy. It should not feel like essentially every time a scav sprays it is a coin flip whether they will either completely miss 15 shots in a row or beam you in the head with no in between. I am not kidding when I say the scavs will miss just enough to make you comfortable and then randomly you will see a scav peek a corner and absolutely lay out your whole squad. Its kind of insane.

Ok i was torn weather i give this a positive review. 

In the end i refunded it because it's not my taste. I like survival games that are more complex. That said i've spend most of the time shooting AI enemies and running to a trader to sell items. Thats the PVE side, extremly boring. PVP however has it's thrilling moments. So if you plan on buying this for PVE, don't! PVP is where it's at and that's also what the game centers on. Hence the raid mechanics and simplyfied, not very well tought out survival aspects, they seem to be just tacked on and what you are really playing is deathmatch on a large map. 

It's that kind of review where i wish there was a button for a middle ground between good and bad. Or a "Not my taste button" because in itself for what it want's to be, the game isn't bad and i think it would really shine with mod support. 

Thumbs up for the PVP players!

After playing this game some more,
I can say that this game has potential. It provides a PVP/PVE experience that doesn't require insane amounts of grinding. The missions and events in this game are fun to do and provide you most of your loot/cash. The way raiding in this game works is great too. With the way it is setup, offline raids don't really exist. When someone kills you, you have a chance to drop a raid token which will disappear within 5 minutes if not used. When used, it highlights a large area where your base is located for 60 minutes, allowing your base to be raided in that time period. The NPCs in this game can either be easy pickings or extremely deadly. 
Overall, this game is worth the money if you are looking for a game similar to Rust without the grinding and time investment requirement. Its good fun and I do hope to see more from this game.

Bought this game on a whim and couldn't be happier. Don't let the steam charts player count scare you away from this game. There are dedicated servers in this game that always have players in it.

Unlike DayZ and Rust, you can find guns almost immediately when spawning in, in houses and shelters. So you aren't spending hours looking for a firearm, magazines, and ammo. Guns in this game spawn with ammo.

The game currently has two safe zones that you are able to enter and store some of your loot or even sell it to one of the two vendors. One vendor sells ammo, guns, and armor/clothing. The other vendor sells building/crafting supplies and food/meds.

My favorite thing about this game is that there are no OFFLINE RAIDS so you aren't glued to the game like Rust. Depending on the server, when you die you have a chance to drop a raid token and if someone pops the raid token within 5 mins of your death, it triggers your base to be open to be attacked and large general proximity of your base is shown on the map any everyone has ~60 mins to attack. Once the timer is up, you can no longer be raided unless you die and drop another raid token and someone pops it.
