Definitely a cool game so far.  I've been looking for a survival game like this for a while!  As of now, I have 3 hrs in the game.  That being said, I definitely haven't seen everything.  However I do have cons along with my pros.

CONS
-The game could use a little bit of work on the gun play. I understand it is not supposed to feel snappy and "arcady", it could definitely be tightened up a little bit.  It seems to lack that satisfying feel or "punch" when engaging in firefights.
-The sound!!! So, I'm torn because some elements are okay.  Atmosphere, gun sounds, and reverberation sounds pretty good by themselves.  HOWEVER, it can be extremely difficult to determine the direction and pin point the sound's origin.  As far as i can tell ( I may be forgetting ) enemy footstep sounds aren't there.  But probably the most frustrating thing at times, AI enemies don't speak or in any way alert you to their presence other than their physical appearance.  Other games usually have ai speaking, breathing or coughing every once in a while so you know that they are present.  

PROS
-Very pretty game.  I play in 4k on a c2 OLED and while it's simple, it is nice to look at.
-Performance.  My rtx3070 for the most part doesn't drop below 100fps on medium to high settings.
-Looting and economy.  This game's economy and looting are simple and easy to understand, it also leaves the player with many meaningful ways to craft and earn towards good and genuinely helpful items.  What stands out with this game is the prevalence of weapons and items.  This helps early game and you can easily gain 3 weapons and a full inventory.
-This can be enjoyed solo or with friends.  You'll definitely enjoy this more with some pals but the atmosphere and stakes make for an awesome solo experience, especially if you notice small details.
-Community.  The player base seems to be more helpful and welcoming to new players than not.  While you'll certainly find yourself killing other players, you'll definitely still have fun with others too.
It's like DayZ and Escape from Tarkov had a baby.

This game is $40 more than it should be worth in its state. Perfect if you love running long distances for literally minutes at a time, only to get shot by a convoy 200 meters away wielding shotguns. Or maybe you misstep and die with a ton of gear and, whiie running back to your base, a level 3 mission pops up and you're forced to abandon everything after the bots detect you sneaking around the trees naked. But hey, realistic gunplay, right? Boosted damage from military AI bots makes sense, since the Army trains you to shoot harder apparently. They can also dome you from over 100 meters away with a shotgun, but fuck you if you try to do it. It's also physically impossible to go prone, not that it would help the heat-seeking AI bots anyways. 

Even if all that [i]doesn't[/i] move you (lord knows it didn't me), you still have to contend with a dying playerbase, and lord f*cking help you if you pick a private server and the f*cking admin decides to make it private in the middle of the night cuz some rando took his loot or something. 

But hey, for the casual fan among you, let me detail your first few moments in the game. You spawn in with a knife, probably around a level 1 mission where people are still stupid accurate with shotguns and pistols. So you'll have to knife a weapon, which a lot of you probably won't do, and so you'll die. 

My favorite part about this review, though, is when the devs inevitably see this and ban me down the road for some asinine reason; a common thread if you look through enough bad reviews of this game. So watch out if you review this as 'helpful', since they're probably compiling a list of those users too. 

So hey, if you like Russians, having things incredibly lopsided for you in the name of 'realism', love spending literally five minutes just running, major updates maybe about twice a year, sh*tty and dying playerbase. As for me, I'm going back to DayZ.

But hey, at least this game now has boats.

I love it. So great not to have zombies everywhere in every game. People (bots) are dangerous enough. I find it a bit of a chore to assemble the tools to build my first base. AI seems to have laser eyes. ;-) I like the great expanse of terrain, but it also feels a bit empty between villages - speedrunning like a devil across the map to get anywhere. I'd love if the vest/rig was expanded into two slots - so that one could wear a hunting vest on top of a bullet proof vest to get best of both worlds if no actual plate molle carrier was available. I think knife and pistol should have their own designated slots as the knife has its utility value at all times. A gas stove would be nice. Random patrols or loners would be nice to have on the map too. Yet to see or use any vehicle - maybe that's for the future too. I stick to PvE as they are difficult enough for me without human players praying on me.

I dont even know where to start with this game. This game just really doesnt have a whole lot going for it. One of my biggest complaints about this game, is the world just feels SO EMPTY and basic. Like verrry empty feeling. There is no wildlife, no bugs, nothing blowing in the wind. The only thing there is, is a few AIs every now and then, that are EXTREMELY stupid and basic. They are so dumb. They just run around, and fire like a 3 y/o is controlling them. Walk up to you slowly firing, sometimes will hit you like they turned aimbot on
for a second. Going back to how empty and character-less the game world is, I didnt see ONE dynamic prop in the whole time i played, i dont think there even is any. The WHOLE game/map is full of STATIC PROPS. The trees are static props, the buildings are static props, objects you pick up in game are static props. Literally every thing in the game, is a static prop. It makes the world SO BORING and basic. I mean the trees dont blow in the wind, you shoot an object, and it just sits there unaffected. 

Another thing I didnt like is the physics, they felt so cheap and generic. Nothing felt like it had any "weight" to it. Just felt like some basic physics programming, with my player clipping through walls and such. Also found "floating" buildings and stuff, which really shows how much effort was put into this game.


The thing this game really needs is ZOMBIES. Yes. Zombies, because it solves a few issues, it gives the world a bit more character, gives you an actual reason to use your weapon and collect ammo, gives you something to survive against, and its the ONE enemy, where its actually ok to have a stupid AI for. Also with a name like "DeadSide" how could you not have zombies in it? ha.

Also this game really should also have Linux support. Not really any reason it shouldnt.


In order for this game to be good, it needs some serious work, so much work in fact, that i really dont even know if its possible. At least i dont think the devs are willing to put enough work into it to make it good. Cause right now, its extremely generic, empty, and honestly pretty boring. There really just isnt any point to play it.

Deadside is one of the most solo-friendly open-world PvP survival games. Love to solo DayZ, Rust, ARK and Tarkov but want something a little more respectful of your time? Pick up Deadside.

I'm in no way saying it doesn't have issues, because it does and they can be VERY disruptive... but picking the right server makes a massive difference. I'd stay away from anything that doesn't have solid admins.

I highly recommend "Loaf's Bakery" if you love PvP but hate 3rd-person perspective. Admins are always on, it restarts constantly for stability, and it's run by the game's own Lead Community Manager. Together they host PvP events for the server - for instance, there's a bracketed 3v3 arena-style PvP tourney today.

10/10 would get beamed by Loaf again.

...

BEAF.

I mean... devs are certainly in the right direction. I just hope for a deeper PvE survival development.
More animals to hunt, rain, maybe some sickness to give some use to pills... and definitely work on more base build features.
And I think PvP should be restricted in sections across the map, for obvious toxic reasons.

Newest update brought long awaited features and fixes to several issues mentioned in previous review.
Overall game feels to be running better (in terms of graphic performance), most of the bugs have been fixed Hurray!
New AI on convoy bots made this event more interesting and fight are longer with better loot from reward (box).
Boats are nice additional feature that makes moving across the map way faster and it gives new tactical opportunities.
New economy however seems to be unpolished and need adjusting.
One of the biggest problems that still exist are flying bases, this is a thing that need to be fixed asap.
Anyway, I can recommend it to any new player who can have a ton of fun for small amount of money.

I'm very disappointed. I've played this game a lot more of this game now, and it's become more apparent to me how empty this game is. I keep trying to love it, but it just feels like the developers don't really want to try in making things better about the experience of this game. 

The AI can STILL see through shrubs and bushes and laser you to death (it's gotten slightly better at a distance, but it's still ridiculous how accurate they are, and how quickly they can kill you, even with really good gear. There's also basically NO cover in forests, which is like 75% of the map. I love the fact that DayZ has trees everywhere with no Robocop-like aim, while this game needs it but doesn't. Just funny how the gaming landscape doesn't listen or just drops things in for no real reason.

The community is also incredibly toxic for the most part. On my first day playing the game, myself and my partner were absolutely wiped by a squad, who used the fact that they had gear to taunt us, make us feel like shit, and continue to abuse their power. There's not a REAL WAY in game to even report people, so you have to email them in order to report anything, which probably makes it easier for people to be abusive and do what they want. On top of this, a lot of the people in the Discord are either rude, despondent, or arrogant. There have been some people that I've met in-game who have been really nice, and a few in the Discord(s), but that's about it.

It's also the worst thing any piece of media can be--boring. The gameplay loop ends incredibly quickly, the missions become boring after doing them for a playtime of about 40 hours, and the world doesn't have any story. I would love to be able to offer more support to this game, but EVERY time I have, I either get arrogant, egotistical people in their Discord (their main place of communication with the community) or no response. That's not to say everyone is like that, but that's what happens most of the time. It's absolutely ridiculous. It's the worst thing you can do to a community of players--keep them at a distance and shoot them down for no real reason. There are only a few that are close to the development (Like Loaf, from my experience) who genuinely care about people and try to make their opinions feel heard. I have SO MANY ideas for this game and I was so optimistic, but the Discord and the updates have just left me feeling empty about the game as a whole.

I'm not saying don't play this game. Maybe one or two of these things will change, or at the very least improve. Maybe even all of them will--but I doubt it personally. Ultimately, I'm just disappointed. 

I want to love this game, but I just can't. I want to play it, but I just can't. I want to be invested in this game, but I can't.

DeadSide is more than your typical FPS, IMO. Servers host PVP, PVE, and PVPVE worlds that are not very easy to thrive. After you pay your dues, things get easier but never easy. Build your base. Build your clan. Build yourself. With ongoing quests/missions, static NPC protected bases, and NPC patrols I think you will have more than enough to do...as usual, there might not be enough time in the real world to get it all done in a day.

There is a trading system in place, run by NPCs...everything has a value!

Many Deadside servers have Admins who are there to ensure fair play, and might offer a nudge for struggling players...<shrug>...Pick it up and see for yourself.

PvE private servers set to high loot make for a suitable casual challenge. Only a light sprinkling of trolls and loot thieves. Adding more admin tools will solidify what admins can do to eliminate those people from the private server experience.

Utter garbage. It's almost as if the dev's took a look at the exile mod for arma 3 and decided to do that, but only if it was absolute shit.

There are no monsters, no zombies, not even a bird. Just heavily armed npc's with deadshot aimbot that can shoot you between the eyes before you even have a chance to know they exist.

Game is online only, no local play or solo available, forcing you to rely on server halfway around the world.
Game is based off looting and crafting but offers no loot and has the most barebones crafting system possible.

You spawn in with nothing but a knife in a world populated by heavily armed npc's.

Updates are few and far between, but seem to mostly be empty promises. Dev's have talked about the same piece of content for over a year but have yet to deliver. 

Overall, game looks good and has potential, but its been 3 years since release and the game still hasnt hit its main milestone it put out on launch.

1/10 do not recommend

Es ist eigentlich recht einfach. Man findet in jeder Stadt ein paar Medis, Essen/Trinken, Waffen und genug Munition.

Das Handeln:
Es gibt Safezones und weitere Händler auf der Map bei denen man gut Kohle verdienen kann um sich neue Sachen/Ausrüstung/Waffen zu kaufen.

Umgebung/Grafik:

So first something positive. There is a duck whistle that's the coolest thing in the game :p

no, let's be honest now... Yes, the game is in early access, but it's been almost 3 years now.
It just doesn't happen... Updates are announced and then only installed after months... There are fewer and fewer servers... Players aren't getting any more either...
If you get the game for a euro then buy it, otherwise you'd rather invest your money in another game

I'll start with the positive.

Building:
So from the construction limit it is completely sufficient to build a good and safe base.

The weapons:
There is a wide range of weapons. There are a few melee weapons and lots of MP's, snipers or machine guns.

Surviving:
It's actually quite simple. You can find some meds, food/drink, weapons and enough ammo in every town.
You can also build a radio that warns you of NPCs.

The missions:
Are actually well divided from easy to epic. The bots aren't completely stupid either and are flanking.
There is also a cargo drop from time to time in which weapons etc. can be found.

The Trade:
There are safe zones and other dealers on the map where you can earn good money to buy new things/equipment/weapons.

Environment/Graphics:
There are enough towns/villages to loot. The graphics are also very good.


From time to time there are a few updates such as the large bunker system which can be really demanding.


Now for the negative...

In this day and age it should be possible to stick yourself on the road to stop the convoy :p

no honestly...

- The weapons can jam from 75%
- Unfortunately, it happens too often that you are simply kicked with an error while running
- There is a wipe after every major update (on some servers also after smaller updates)
- When sniping, he can hold his breath for exactly 2 seconds... for 2 seconds...
- Cracking a base is only possible if you have killed the owner and then he still has it
  drops a dog tag... Otherwise you can only blow up the crates and don't get the loot.
- The bots will see you through bushes etc and then kill you with one shot
- The clothes/armor do not show any stats such as defense etc. You can only look at the selling price
   see
  if a piece of armor is better.
- Fast travel is just way too expensive. 3 dog tags so you have to complete an epic mission
   do
- Crates in the base disappear after 7 days if you don't use them
- Dog tags are too rare. Depending on the mission you get 1-3 pieces
- There are no vehicles
- You can swim but not dive. So you're an easy target in the water
- There are still some sound bugs. You just hear a river or something like that
- Trees or the direction finder are reflected in the sea
- When building a base, the boxes are limited to 6 pieces, no matter how many players are registered in a base
- The game stutters from time to time.
- The horde of flies over a corpse... Yes, if you are directly on a mission, they are very
   loud^^
- Missions disappear if you don't do them in the direct area but at a distance
- The weapon simply pulls up when firing if you stand too close to the wall
- You can't lie down, making the ghillie suit a bit unnecessary

(TLDR at bottom) First thing's first, the idea of Deadside is great and the PvP is incredibly fun (When the game works). Unfortunately that"s where the good stuff ends. The Dev's have made no real progress towards what they stated they wanted the final product to be, there is barely any structure to the world. The Game has been on steam for 3 years now and can barely call itself a competitor in the genre. There is no tangible endgame or anything to grind for as you can acquire any item in the game within a few hour of playtime, the only items that require you to put in time and genuine effort to get are just weapons and gear with camo. The updates are so far and few in between that you'll play for maybe a week before going on a six month hiatus. Only a few of the maps poi's have real cover and the base building is a lesser (although wonderfully less complicated) version of DayZ's. My final complaint in this overly long rage review is with the enemy AI. There is no in game function to tell the AI when they've lost line of sight on a player through something that the player themselves can not see through (I.E. Bushes, shrubbery, and at at night with how dark this game gets.) The AI all have the same accuracy at all levels of difficulty, a simple bandit with a low tier pistol will hit the same amount of shots as an epic difficulty soldier will with a Ar4 (M4) at the same range of 350M, 7 out of 10 shots will hit you on average if you stand still in the middle of a field. They also have ridiculous health with no body armor whatsoever and as soon as one sees you they all be line for you like zombies in WWZ. The AI are supposed to be half of the games combat and way to get loot and they are unbearable to fight.       TLDR: Massive Update gaps, very buggy, very short grind and hellish AI combat after 3 years of development

Deadside is like DayZ meets Tarkov and had a baby. It's a far more simplified game than either of those two, which to me was refreshing and lots of fun to play. The game runs well (mostly) for still being under development. There is plenty of room to expand the map, content, and features but very fun to play in its current state. I got this on sale and quickly put 60+ hours into it, then went back for the Supporter Pack which expands your storage space and adds a few more items to your respawn kit...a great value for what I spent.Currently there is plenty of map and POI's to explore, loot, and conquer. I played mostly on a PVE server against the AI, which come in different levels of difficulty from easy up to epic. I found it challenging, but not overwhelming. The player community has been great and helpful teaching me the game. They even helped rescue me when I got in over my head at a Hard mission site...probably not what happens on a PVP server lol.In summary, this is more of a gun action game than a survival game, but has elements of survival & base building. There are NPC traders to sell extra loot and store some items like Tarkov, but the gameplay feels more like DayZ running through forests and fields to loot or get into gunfights in villages and military bases. The user interface (UI) is very similar to DayZ and Tarkov, and was easy for me to figure out quickly. I ended up rebinding a few commands, like the in-game chat button, but overall it's very familiar to me. I look forward to future updates with more content and features.
Deadside Deadgame

Deadside is a multiplayer survival game developed by Bad Pixel. The game is set in an open-world environment where players have to explore and scavenge for resources, while also fending off hostile AI enemies and other players.

In terms of gameplay, Deadside offers a unique blend of survival, PvP, and PvE elements. Players can choose to play solo or in groups, and must work together to build bases, craft weapons, and gather resources to survive. The game also features a robust loot system, with various types of gear and weapons that can be found throughout the world.

One of the strengths of Deadside is its emphasis on realism. The game features realistic ballistics, damage models, and environmental effects that make combat feel visceral and intense. The game also has a strong emphasis on tactical gameplay, with players needing to carefully plan their movements and coordinate with their teammates to stay alive.

However, Deadside is not without its issues. The game is still in early access, and as such, it can be buggy and prone to crashes. The game's UI and controls can also be clunky and unintuitive at times, making it difficult for new players to get started.

Overall, Deadside is a solid survival game that offers a unique blend of PvP and PvE elements. While it has its share of issues, it's still an enjoyable game that's worth checking out for fans of the genre.

The best in the field so far. I really like the tarkov style scavs. The ai is far from perfect. I've been spotted by them 150m out but it beats the cracked zombies in similar titles. This game feels further developed than both DayZ and Scum which are filled with "hardcore" survival annoyances surrounded by emptiness. Those games are super empty and the official servers are whack. At least DEADSIDE has an interactive map with events and missions to go do. You can also easily find and group up with friends. I've been waiting over 10 years for a base game to give me what modded Arma 3 did. Only thing missing is vehicles and I feel more weapons need to be added. Also highly need more options for food and water cause you have to really grind to obtain food/drink currently. I 1000% regret not buying this back when I watched Eroktic play it but I was over how poorly implemented similar titles are still till this day... so I avoided this for a long time. This game still needs a lot of polishing but is far ahead of it's competition. Scum and DayZ both lied to me and filled me with false promises. Social interaction is better in DayZ while Deadside is much more PVP based but i'm telling you what you see is what you get with this game.

I gave Deadside a try for about 25 minutes, but unfortunately, it didn't capture my interest. The game feels very generic and lacks the excitement and innovation that I expect from a survival game.

One of the major downsides is that there are no vehicles available, which makes exploring the large map feel like a chore. Additionally, the game is still in early access, so there are some bugs and glitches that need to be ironed out.

However, I am willing to give it another chance in the future because I love this genre. I understand that the devs are actively working on improving the game, and I hope to see more content and features added soon.

Overall, I cannot recommend Deadside in its current state. But if the devs address the issues and add more interesting features, it could become a great survival game.

It's like DayZ meets Tarkov but more casual, faster paced and PVP focused. 

Pros:

+ Performance (runs super well and smoothly, 120+fps on my RTX 2060 SUPER)
+ Graphics (not next gen or mind blowing but for how well it runs it looks really good)
+ PVP mechanics (easy to find fights/get into fights, TTK is fast and deadly)
+ No OFFLINE raiding (personally a fan of this, the way they did it you can only online raid)
+ Plenty of cool + modded communities (there's a range of servers from vanilla pve to modded pvp)

Cons:

- AI (they are pretty dumb and simultaneously cracked AF, being stupid accurate and deadly at times, able to see you through bushes, tall grass ect...)
- Lack of transport options = a good chunk of running (Only 3 ways of getting around the map currently; running, killing yourself and respawning, using the overpriced tunnel system to fast travel to the other safezone)
- Some bugs (as with EA expect some bugs, i.e. getting glitched into a wall and not being able to move or shoot)

Die Entwickler (Russen) sind sehr unfreundlich (kein Danke bei Vorschlägen oder wenn man einen Bug gemeldet hat) & sehr empfindlich, wenn es um das Thema Cheaten geht. Ich wurde aus der Deadside-Community gesperrt, weil sie mich beschuldigen, Cheats zu vermarkten, was überhaupt nicht der Fall ist. Der Name des Anklägers ist Damien. Ich bin gegen jeglichen Betrug in Computerspielen, was ich auch in meinem Youtube-Video deutlich gemacht habe. Die Sprache des Videos ist auf Englisch. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mtbwFNeLnpg&ab_channel=vollindiemoehre

Ich denke, dass einige FPS-Spiele-Entwickler Geld für den Verkauf von Cheats verdienen, also wollen sie nicht, dass das Thema Cheats zu weit an die Öffentlichkeit gelangt, um nicht für Unruhe innerhalb der Community Ihres Spiels zu sorgen. Ich kann neuen Spielern empfehlen, nicht auf dem offiziellen Europa-Server 220 FP only zu spielen, da es dort viele Cheater gibt. Es ist eine Gruppe von Cheatern, die sich vermutlich abwechseln mit dem cheaten. Außerdem sollte man als Beweis dafür, dass man von einem Cheater getötet wurde, sein Gameplay aufzeichnen und es anschließend melden, was aber mit einem zeitlichen Aufwand verknüpft ist. Außerdem brauchen die Entwickler und EAC lange, um Spieler zu bannen, wenn sie den wirklich gebannt werden auf den offiziellen Servern. In meinem Fall leider nicht. Einem Cheater ist nichts passiert, nachdem ich ihn bei devs (lucas) und EAC gemeldet habe. Laut der EAC-Website dauerte es 3-14 Tage, um das Steam Profil zu analysieren. Es gibt keine Ingame Funktion, um verdächtige Spieler zu melden, was ziemlich schlecht ist. Auf privaten Servern, sieht die ganze Sache wiederum anders aus (aktive Admins), weshalb ich empfehle auf privaten Servern zu spielen. Es gibt auch Spieler, die mehr als ein Steam-Konto haben und sich damit auf einem Server anmelden und dies zu ihrem Vorteil nutzen (verschiedene Spawn Möglichkeiten). Manchmal bringen sich die Cheater gegenseitig um, damit Sie ihr KD-Verhältnis verringern, um nicht zu verdächtig zu werden und das Anti-Cheat-Programm sie nicht als Cheater registrieren kann.

In diesem Video seht ihr wie ich von den Devs aus der Community gebannt wurde und wie mit anderen Spielern umgegangen wird, die eigentlich nur Gutes im Sinne haben.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HkcZg5oPOmI&ab_channel=vollindiemoehre

Wichtig: Auf den Spints nicht aus den Tradern ausloggen, dadurch rückt man einen Raum nach oben und beim nächsten Login kommt man ohne Suizid nicht mehr raus, man ist also fast gefangen. Das war sehr ärgerlich für einen Freund, da die gesamte Ausrüstung verloren ging. Die Hitbox funktioniert meiner Meinung nach gut - das DevTeam hat sich nach einer Weile verbessert. Außerdem befinden sich die Bots während Missionen meist an der gleichen Stelle, dies müsste mit mehr zufälligen Spawns geändert werden. Ansonsten fühlt sich das Spiel flüssig an. Die Grafik ist okay und wurde mit dem Update 0.2.0 verbessert. Der Militärbunker sieht schön aus, aber leider fällt es mir schwer mit 50 fps zu spielen. Dies sollte angepasst werden. Ansonsten ein netter Shooter mit Survival-Elementen. Sie können Dinge wie Bandagen, Basisobjekte, Sprengstofffallen, Feuervorräte usw. herstellen. Das Spiel an sich macht bis zu einem gewissen Grad Spaß. Wird aber nach einiger Zeit langweilig.

There are multiple talking points I would like to make in this review.

Gun-play: I have played for around 10 hours now, and I do enjoy the gun-play. I feel as if there is an ok amount of variety currently, but I do believe more weapons/attachments/etc need to be added in order to make this feel fully fleshed out. The actual shooting sounds great, and there have been multiple instances where I have been startled being shot at as I trudged along through the woods looking for more loot to sell. I think shooting is impactful, and leaves me satisfied as I ambush bots around the world, but I also feel as if the lack of variety hinders my feeling of excitement or long-term progression.

Armor/Clothing: I find the aesthetic of the clothing and armor fitting. This point will boil down basically to the same thing as weapons - there just needs to be more variety. Currently, there are three utility vests (vests which provides inventory but no defensive value) and four different armored vests (one that provides inventory as well as a defensive value, while the other three are strictly used as armor). In my 10 hours of gameplay, I have seen them all. Maybe I am being nit-picky, but I do believe to extend the longevity of this games life, it should have more armor variations.

AI: This is an interesting one. The AI in the game has really good aim, but lack the ability to utilize any form of cover. The AI also does not use any form of higher level tactics. This becomes a problem, in my experience, specifically playing solo. As a solo player, if I had planned on completing missions or clearing an AI populated area, I would find myself shooting the first bot from afar, backing up, and then waiting for the rest of the AI to swarm me one by one. This results in repetitive solo fights, as the AI simply charges you while having no other recourse. If a player has little armor, the fact that the AI constantly runs towards you, plus having their above average aim, makes this strategy the most practical yet least enjoyable. As I played I had partied with another random individual in the lobby and we did missions together. This was the most enjoyable period of gameplay I experienced. Even though the AI would charge one of us directly, the other would have a chance to take a shot without being directly assaulted. I believe the solo experience fighting bots is completely different than fighting with partied, and leaves me frustrated some of the time.

Bugs: During my time spent playing I only witnessed a single bug, but in the correct circumstances, it could be devastating. While I had partied with another individual, they had died, and upon relocating their body and attempting to retrieve their loot, they couldn't. I don't remember explicitly what the error said, but it boiled down to "You cannot access this container at this time." For a game where the progression of gear is a main point of gameplay, this would be extremely frustrating. You were shot by bots after grinding for however long in order to obtain high level gear, respawn and run *all the way* back to your body to be told you can't have your stuff. Luckily someone in the lobby gave them some replacement gear, but if that wasn't the case, and I was in their shoes, I probably would have stopped playing right there.

Building: In my short time of gameplay, I actually have not attempted building a base on any server, and plan to do so in the upcoming days. At that time, I would like to update my review to better reflect my opinion on this subject. From what I've heard from active players is that it takes an extremely long time, but I would like to get a first hand account.

Development: Looking at the development of this game, mainly, I have positive feelings. Updates are being pushed out at what I would consider, a pretty fast rate. And that is fantastic, but I do have one minor grievance. Vehicles had been announced with their upcoming update of 0.5, with the sneak peak of hoverboats. I have faith in the devs of this game, as they have been seemingly hard at work, but I do hope that more vehicles are added besides hoverboats. The majority of my time was spent running from point A to B. If any form of land vehicle is added, even with the caveat that they are hard to obtain, I would be happy. This would help extend the enjoyable grind of the game, while also minimizing, what I found to be, one of the least enjoyable aspects of gameplay. I do believe that land vehicles will be added, but they have not been shown, and that leaves me slightly worried. Considering I spend way more time running than swimming, the fact they teased hoverboats but not land vehicles leaves me slightly confused, but this could be written away as them building hype for the map extension. (If they add land vehicles, I will most likely revise parts of this section)

Overall, I enjoy this game. The gunfights, looting, community is all enjoyable. I do get frustrated at the amazing aim of AI, but tend to get past this fact by putting my focus on upgrading my gear. I think with the amount of updates the game is receiving, it has the possibility to be a great game. Some bug fixes here, some more content there. In its current state, it is pretty bare bones, and considering the initial release date was April of 2020, there should be higher quality content in the current version of the game. But with the active updates, I think its safe to presume this game will continue to be developed into something great. I recommend it, but with the warning of bugs and the obvious statement: it is early access still

TLDR
AI is whack sometimes, shallow progression, gunplay is good, some bugs which could be a deal breaker if you are worried about losing hours of grinding, but the devs are seemingly lively and active, and whats here is already good.

EDIT 3/16/2023

As there have been little to no quality updates for this game, I have decided to change my positive review into a negative one. I was hoping to revisit this game at some point, but as there is no new engaging content, I simply do not feel the want or need to. I'd wait until final release on this one.

Very fun game!  I love how the devs have implemented systems into the game so that I can play have fun and still do everything else I have to do in my day without the fear of logging back on the next day to all my progress being wiped out by a player that has more time to play the game than me.  Put simply whereas I enjoy games like Rust, DayZ and other games that allow offline raiding, Deadside to me will always be leagues ahead of them because they only allow for Online Raids (to me the way it should be!).  Very fun PvP, satisfying looting and survival aspects and I'm sure once I find the time to just farm the crafting will be just as enjoyable!  Overall coming from someone who works 40+ hours a week and has a family and children at home Deadside is a game in the Survival PvP genre that even the casual gamer can get loads of fun out of!  I 100% recommend this game to anyone that likes games like Rust and DayZ but is constantly plagued by being Offlined, give Deadside a try and I guarantee you that  you will have just as much fun without being plagued by the threat of an offline raid!

Honestly I tried, I tried really hard to like Deadside. It has some cool things going for it, mainly the gunplay/gunfeel but it has way too many shortcomings and ultimately feels like a game from 10 years ago. There's a clear lack of content, the playerbase is very small and somewhat dedicated, the missions and other events on the map are boring and the NPC's are dumb as rocks. I don't know who this game is for, I would assume EFT or Rust fans looking for something similar but different. Most of the time I found myself wondering why I wasnt playing Tarkov instead, as the FPS view is very clearly inspired by that game. The PVP was fun and the skill level seems pretty low (I've only lost a fight twice in 13h and it was by AR-4 after I killed the first teammate). 

I would recommend against buying this if you don't own EFT, DayZ or Rust. Those 3 games offer more diverse and complete experiences with larger playerbases. Other than that, the only reason I can see for getting Deadside would be a monetary one. It's cheap (and it's evident by the fact that the main playerbase speaks russian or spanish). This is quite literally a third world version of DayZ/Tarkov.

This game checks many boxes when it comes to the "DAYZ" Genre of games. To me its a DAYZ clone that does certain things better. Its basically a stand-alone version of a modded DAYZ server. 

THE GOOD

Open world, FPP or TPP, Heavily focused on PVP with ALOT of PVE elements. 
Everyone has a map, Safe zones, towns, events, missions, everything is clearly marked. 
Every town is a re spawn point! (not random) 
The map is generally smaller than DAYZ, meaning  if you die its a maybe a 600m run to your body which only takes a couple minutes to run that distance. 
Survival elements exist, food and water consumption, as well as hunting for food. 
Loot (weapons) much easier to find, maybe a couple minutes looting and you'll have a pistol or shotgun.
Excellent ragdoll physics, and hits on people are clearly visible with "pink mist" 
Traders exist in safe zones, and offer storage until you have a base. (good for new players)
A Fast travel system, via rail cart (costs dogtags as payment to use it)
A party system exists, meaning you can team up with friends, and easily see them on your HUD, As well as custom markers. 
Base Building! pretty easily done, without a terrible grind, most items are buyable from safezone traders to construct a base. 

THE BAD

No Prone position, all we can do is either crouch or stand.
Food as in finding items to eat, seems to be scarce. you can hunt for food but that requires time, and crafting or finding a campfire to cook it. 
The holding breath system seems a little wonky, its kinda hard to tell when you are and when you arnt doing it anymore. and it seems to only last maybe a second or so, before its so unstable you couldn't dream of hitting anything. 
Needs more interesting POI's there is definitely a lot to explore on the map, and it's filled with a lot more than i expected, but some towns are maybe a group of 2 or 3 buildings.
Placing a land claim sign, is well difficult.....prepare to run around with it out like a madman, until it turns green and will allow you to place it. (took me an hour) 
Updates, as of recently the devs seem to behind with the road map for 2022. the end of 2022, was suppose to see vehicles added, and currently is about 2 or 3 months behind what we were originally told. (and apparantly will be added, when its added.....)

All in all this game has a TON of potential and plays like the modded DAYZ server or ARMA exiles server youve always dreamed of finding with the right mods. Hopefully updates will continue, because this could seriously change the open world/survival genre with the potential this game has!

So, time to edit this BS, after 390 hours, my opinion on this game has changed a little.....game is apparently dysfunctional, buggy trash......

First up: Body poofing and losing loot

This is 6 FUCKING times now that I have had my body and all the loot ive worked for VANISH or lost due to game crashes, glitchy mechanics of BS within the game.  390 hours of game time, that is an average of 65 hours per time I lose my body and all my loot.  At this point, this game can fuck off and die with this shit.  Why bother playing a game where at any moment, out of the blue, all your game progress can be wiped, not by way of you losing it, but by way of the game glitching it out of existance.  I used to think this game ran well to....no, it runs like shit apparently.  It crashes frequently and out of the blue.  

2: The AI

The AI are bullshit, basic PVP Cheaters stuck in the form of an Artificial intelligence.  Their pathing is trash, all they do is yolo straight at you, killing you with their wall hacks, aim bot and ability to see perfectly fine through 100 layers of trees, or even in pitch black darkness...

-Wallhacks: They will see you and shoot you with precision through dense foliage, bushes, trees and can even track you through a building's wall.  Often times you will start hearing gun fire and taking hits, looking around for the target, but dont realize hes behind 10 layers of dense vegetation that not even the most trained and observant eye could ever have a hope in hell of seeing.  

-Aim Bots: While the regular Scavs are not so bad, in fact, they are fair enough and in some cases, id say could use a very mild accuracy buff, the military guys(namely Helicopter crash crew) and the convoy LMG Boss are complete bullshit.  The convoy boss will sit back there at 250-300+ meters and spam his LMG at you, if he hits you with even 1 bullet, you immediately just DIE.  No chance to move, cover, duck, heal, nothing, just DEAD.......  The Helicopter crash crew are less obnoxious, but still have RPKs and Rifles that they are way to accurate with.  If your unable to snipe them all dead before they get within range and start firing, your fubar.  You absolutely cant out shoot them.  They take many, many, many bullets to kill while you take maybe 3.  You combine it with the wack ass weapon sway we have in this game and getting those follow up shots to kill these guys is nigh on impossible. 

-Their health:  While you the player will take maybe 2-3 hits at most, these AI, even the normal scav can eat upwards of 5-8 hits before dying.  Ive had to put no less than 3 SVD rounds into a single normal SCAV on numerous occasions(Confirmation of my hit being the red blood splat on hit).  

3: Gun play

While ive seen many tout it as really good, id say its good, but has some wack ass issues that are compounded by other things.  First up the weapon sway.  While sure, its realistic, you dont just hold your gun rock steady, this does not seem to be applied to the AI, who, while your trying to get your gun back on target while its wobbling around, the AI are just plugging you in the face.  Then you have extremely high bullet spread even on single shots.  So, you take weapon sway, high bullet spread and fairly severe recoil, it makes getting follow up shots on enemies almost impossible.  All the while guys like the Convoy boss and heli crew are just accurately machine gunning you from 150+ meters out.  Next, lets t alk about that whole mechanic where you put your gun up when your near cover.  Ok, yeah, it makes sense, you cant put a gun through a tree, but it makes using cover insanely annoying.  Get near a good tree and try to lean around it, but oh,your 1 foot step to close and now you cant zoom in, So now you get to play footsies with the tree trying to both stay covered from the enemy firing at you and find a position where you can actually lean out to shoot.......
Gun fire retort and muzzle flashes:  This game is SORELY lacking in this department.  The gun fire sounds are way off.  It will sound like the guy is 100-200m away when hes standing right beside you.  There is very little differentiation in distance inthis game.  Makes finding enemies who are firing through dense vegetation impossible.  Ive literally had a guy who managed to, somehow, sneak across an open field and get right beside me, yet the gun fire(as well as my lack of taking any hits), led me to believe he was still 100+ meters away out in that field....he was right behind me......like wow.  

Sooo, in short, the gun play while not flatly terrible just has many mechanics that combine to make it really quite clunky, especially when compared to the cheats and other AI.....shall we say, enhancements.....

4: The inventory

While I get they dont want you walking around with 20 tons of loot all at once, there are things they could definitely do to improve the overall situation and make it a little less clunky to use.  First thing they could do is let you store more guns in your damn bags.  Your unable to store rifles in your bag.  Your also unable to store attachments ON guns and put them in your bags or bank.  This results in your already very limited stash and bag space being sucked up by multiple attachments.  Then, if you want to say, swap an SVD for an M4, you first have to take the 2 attachments off your SVD, then DROP the SVD on the floor, because you cant take it with you.  Then, equip the M4, then put all the attachments on that.  Its tedious and far more time consuming than it could be. 

The same is true of the actual inventory space.  Unlike almost every other MMO/RPG type game ive played, you can simply drag and drop to swap items.  Say your wearing a heavy assault vest, but want to wear a vest with more space.  You first have to take off the heavy vest, put it in an empty spot in the inventory(hard to do when your already loaded down with loot), then put the other vest ON, then put the heavy vest in the inventory.  Its just really clunky, slow and tedious.  This is the only game ive seen do it this way.....

Like I said, game has solid promise and its got a good foundation, but it needs alot of polish and refinement.  LOsing a weeks worth of top tier gear,(matching Flecktarn facemask, pants, shirt, STALKER backpack, my compensator, a camod M99 out of the bunker, keys for the bunker, among other things), has just absolutely killed the game for me.  That they have that kind of system where you can sol easily lose everything you've worked for is just a solid NO in my book.  FIx this game, make it more intuitive, less clunky, get rid of the AI cheats and you've got yourself a solid game.

This game is highly under-rated. Yes the distances will make it seem like the game is a "walking simulator" but it's not as bad as it's played out to be. There are systems that you need to invest time into, and in turn, the game opens up even more. The ambient audio is done really well, the map and UI are excellent, dynamic missions and weather that keep the world active and alive and weapons and items are abundant. A very solid foundation that I hope is given more time, resources and development to see this game be given the attention it deserves!

It's pretty cool how AI can beam you through 150ft of Bushes. Honestly if they did a little more adjustment to the AI I'd give a positive review but for now I have to say Negative. Other aspects of the game are good, the gun play isn't anything revolutionary but it's decent. The Trader is a little iffy, if more was added to them, it would be alright but as is certain items cannot be sold (i.e food) and the roaming trader is a decent Idea in concept but needs to be touched up on a bit, bringing all your money to the traveling trader only to find out it's the equipment guy and you need guns or vice versa, gets a bit annoying after a while. The missions are alright, similar to the ones seen in the DayZ mods, but again with the AI, they just tend to be annoying and tedious. The map is beautiful and the ambient sounds are a nice touch but when you can't see the AI doming you with a double barrel from 150ft away through the thick lush boreal forest, it kind've gets a little tedious and repetitive. I feel like instead of trying to add a boat in game, maybe focus more on some Q.O.L for the time being. I'll still be watching for updates but the games almost been out for 3 years now, I don't have much faith.

A once promising and flourishing game, it has unfortunately taken a turn for the worst since it has been taken over by Tiny Build. The previous team, Bad Pixel, developed a visually immaculate third/1st person option shooter survival set in modern post apocalyptic world with real world weaponry and gear. Unfortunately the small dev team (Bad Pixel) couldn't bring their full game to fruition on their own and signed the game over to Tiny Build who promised they shared the common vision and goals as the originators. Since the take over we've seen unpolished mechanics and game play make it's way into game play. For example, an update removed the option to purchase food in the safe zone in lieu of a canteen to assist with hydration, a key feature in survival games. The canteen is a single use item that cannot be filled in any of the bodies of water located on the map. A recoil pattern spray update was also implemented. Has anyone ever heard of a third person shooter with recoil pattern? How would/could this work? While there are many other issues regarding implementations, other pressing issues to discuss exist such as glitches. One of which is a crouch glitch where you crouch and wedge yourself under a overhanging rock or tree branch, log out, log in, and viola, you're now in another part of the map. Another such glitch is when you die from falling, being killed in air, or your body rolls down hill. When this occurs, you cannot loot your body and all those hours of looting are wasted. The last issue at hand is the lack of vehicles. This game is a running simulator so get ready to build up your finger dexterity! The dev team continues to promise the release of vehicles while missing road map release dates time after time with the promise that they're still working on it. Vehicles have actually been down graded to open platform boats and this is somehow supposed to be appeasing. I'm not saying this game is a complete loss but at this rate and with the lack of meaningful updates, it's looking that way. At the end of the day you can always try it out and get a refund. Good luck out there and have fun.

While this game can definitely keep you occupied scouring the map for supplies, battling bots as well as other players, and completing the same missions with different difficulty  (it just depends on the amount of bots they cram into a town and weapons they have). There is no tutorial to get you started, or any guidance what so ever, I have no idea how much of this game i'm actually missing out on. None the less this game feels like it is not finished, and after giving it an honest try for hours, can honestly say do not waste your money unless you're just looking to waste your time. There's no true objective, there's a very irritating message that pops up on the screen every minute or two letting you know that your mission has failed and a new one has appeared, very limited weapons, 3rd person looks okay but there's no retical if you aim it just goes back first person, bots will shoot you from over 100 km away with a little makarov pistol while hiding in a bush giving you pretty serious damage that takes a while to heal. There is no reward system and all the bots you do manage to kill have zero loot besides their clothes and weapon. Then when you die, you get sent to some village kind of close by to your death (not really), with your same exact starting gear. This game has so much potential but it just feels like it was too rushed and poorly put together. I wish vigor would come out for pc. Still looking for an awesome looter shooter.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I have roughly 11-12 hours at the time of this review. Take all of this with a grain of salt as i have limited experience thus far and the game is subject to changes at any point as it's still early access. 
Pros: 
-Runs extremely smooth on an old pc with limited resources. 
-Graphics are good for early access and game has very little chop.
-Realistic damage. 2 hits and you are done. 12ga early game is a ripper!
-Team play is exciting and communication is essential.
-I personally love the safe zones and trader aspect. 
-Prices of items is steep, as it should be. 
-Loot is pretty available and most items have a use other than just for sale value.
-Map is extremely well thought out and while easy to navigate, has plenty of danger spots and terrain is varied enough to keep the game from suffering the Walking Simulator aspect so many survival games suffer from.
-Health, hunger, and thirst are super simple mechanic and easy to address. Though healing takes some time! shoot, move, medicate, repeat.  
Cons:
-25km/sq seems big, but with more than 10-15 people (50 max per server atm) it gets well chaotic! 
-Base building takes FOREVER to gather enough wood and supplies. It does however force the player to raid towns for nails, tools, and other materials.
-Missions are extremely hard solo. 

Overall i give this game an 8.5/10. It's still early in the dev phase and I see this game easily pulling more casual players from Tarkov, Rust, Miscreated, Scum, and DayZ.  While this game could be a very serious raiding game and pvp, it's simplicity is it's biggest asset. No need to memorize 10,000 different items and their market price etc. Weapons are easily modded and no need for special mounts for EACH weapon. Grab a scope, put it on your 556 bolty and wreak havoc! Missions are extremely fun with a duo or trio but solo ...quite the challenge if you aren't already somewhat Chadded up. I do highly recommend this product WITH the supporter pack as early on...it's almost essential.  My son and I both had the upgrade and still filled our inventory very quickly with bullets, crafting supplies, and construction materials. Despite any of it's downsides, this is probably one of the best and most fun Early access games I have purchased to date.

Update: 450+ hours  -  This game has only gotten better and better. The Devs are super active and responsive to the community and the new weapon sound effects are top notch. The updated building system is much more streamlined and takes much less time to build a base. The map has expended and so much more has been added and vehicles and ANOTHER map addition are being added very shortly, all at ZERO extra cost out of my wallet, aka no paid DLC required. 9/10 and highly recommend.

This game is a MUCH better game than other big name survival games such as Day-Z. You won't freeze to death, you won't spend a ton of time searching for food and water, so you get to spend more time doing what you want to do in this game. Shooting people and killing enemies.

The enemy AI in this game are PMC's and Bandit's instead of zombies, which is also a huge plus. First of all, because they can shoot back, and their aim scales to difficulty depending on how well trained they are. Bandits typically can't hit the broadside of a barn, but high armored PMC's can one tap you in the face with a mosin. But you also don't have to worry about some timmy that sucks at every game he plays coming in and third partying you to get a free kill while you are fighting off a hoard of zombies, just to kill you and get an unsupressed pistol with 9 shots in it, because he heard a gunshot from 2 miles away.

The game could use vehicles, but to my understanding that's coming. So, if you want to play a game like Day Z but 1000x better than Day Z, play this game. Even at full price it's less expensive than the ON SALE price of that garbage ass game.

Let me start off with me saying this game is amazing, I love fighting the AI lot more then DAYZ fighting zombies. Gun play is amazing and graphics are impeccable. Recommend

Pros: 
- decent survival mechanics.
- interesting mission area mechanics and dynamic events.
- Weapon/ammo variation available in game is very good.

Cons:
- buttons in game do not line up properly to press correctly.
- AI is either the dumbest in any game, or 2-3 bullet kill LASER you, even if > l l much is barely showing of you, you still get hit. 
- brush is 100% ineffective against AI.
- armor does little to nothing to help you survive, maybe 1 more bullet extra.
- 2x scope has a terrible and unrealistic reticle, as it doesn't even come close to a cross hairs. just a vague open area in the lines.
- sometimes food/water scarcity is too much and not really a lot of opportunities to acquire without a base to cook/get water.
- there is no holding breath for sights/scopes (at least that im aware of) and the scope sways A LOT.
- no real variation in AI weapons, basically the same half a dozen weapon drops, 2 type shotgun, 2 type rifle, 2 type pistol, and 1-2 type smg, MAYBE.
- too many healables take away from water fullness in an already scarce environment.

final assessment- basically only worth maybe 5 dollars, no more than 10, needs a lot of work and things streamlined. kinda clunky in most respects, tries hard with some cool mechanics, but falls short due to ranged weapons being fairly ineffective so a lot of fights are you getting killed in mid-long range fights as due to sway/crummy reticle its hard to make shots connect, or just a shotgun with CQB and cheese any AI that comes around the corner with instant kills. after hours playing, even with a base, the game becomes redundant at best.

Let me give an advice : play carefully and with sound.

This game is my favorite among all those that exist of the same genre (quite similar to stalker). It is hard yes, frustrating yes, but so enjoyable.
It is possible to play fully alone (as I did over +50h) but quite hard when you start and know nothing about game mechanics. The game will punish you if you believe that you're on Call Of Duty and rush like a retard. 

The most enjoyable points : 

* Graphics : quite beautiful BUT don't forget to add dx12 as parameter. It will give you a huge rise of FPS .
* Weapons & customizations : before having all weapons, you will have to play a bit.
* Survival : you can eat & drink like stalker. Building some stuff to cook and the like.
* Frequent updates & devs aware of community.

The most shitty points :

* AI in hard zone & above : they litteraly have an aimbot killing you at 200-300 meters.
* When you die, you need to walk to your stuff and some zones have poor & far respawn points.
* Some zones are so far away from safezones (when you loot good stuff and have 2km to go back, the game evolves to a hiking simulator).

Conclusion : this is not a game everyone will like. You can give it a try at your own risk but don't complain about game's difficulty. 
Many updates are planned with new contents and I hope the devs won't give up their game.

It is a young game in the development sense compared to the others in this arena but it has solid bones and after a couple of years more of development with features present in others that lead the way it will be a very solid game.  I am not saying it is not a solid game but it is called Early Access for a reason.

My number one gripe is the players themselves.  It is a hardcore survivor PvP so expect death and lots of it. This is what you get but I tried several servers and everyone that had a couple dozen or more players on it had groups patrolling spawn points. 

As a new player more than once I could not make it to the Safe Zone or a few buildings to find a gun for that matter without be hunted down by a group of two or three actual players (not AI which look like players).  When you spawn in you do not have anything of value so to me this is just toxic behaviour that drives away people that would like to give the game a try. This includes me and while from what I experienced it is a great game for the stage of development it is in and has the potential to be a leader in the field but this toxic behaviour has me pausing hitting the Launch button.

Maybe this is why according to Steam Charts only 300 - 800 people are usually playing compared to the other games that will have 10,000 - 30,000 people playing.

This is the most underrated pvp survival game ever made. I’ve played DAYZ for years and SCUM a bit. 

This is DAYZ lite +Tarkov. You get loot fast and can go do numerous events fighting scavs and other players. All with base building and survival elements and hunting. 

The people talking about crashes are too stupid to switch to dx12. Once you run it in dx12 I haven’t had one crash. 

This game deserves a huge player base. Perfect to play with those friends who think DAYZ is too boring and vehicles are about to come out for the game. 

Right now there are plenty of servers that are packed but the game deserves many more players. Honestly servers with full 50 players is almost too much. 20-30 is great.

Best advice I can give is. Second click clothing and tare it up. 
Clothing on the ground = Tare it up, Clothing on dead NPC = Tare it up, 
Find better clothing than what you have now? = Swap and Tare up the things you were wearing. 
Then when you find alcohol make sterilized bandages from the rags you were collecting.

I also find the best place to live (on a PVE server) is in a bathtub of one of the apartment blocks.
Cans of food and drink spawn all around you. Bad guys spawn on the roof to give you ammo. You are close enough to easy missions and a safezone. 
 
Also watch beginners guides on YouTube.

I wanted to like this game, but it has some crazy annoying issues that cannot be overlooked or understated. After about 55 hours of gameplay, I encountered so many issues with the game that I do not feel it is worth the purchase. 

Primary issues.

1.	The gameplay is buggy and awkward. Some are simple things like glitchy graphics or confusing equipment descriptions (or a total lack of descriptions and instructions for anything). Still, there are programming and stability issues that are horrendous. For example, if you die on a hill and your body ragdolls even an inch from the exact spot of your death, you will not be able to recover the equipment you have been working on and saving for. This would be understandable for an early-release game as it is still being developed, but Steam pages and forums are dedicated to this issue going back over two years, and it is still a problem. The game crashes frequently.

2.	If you thought this game was about monsters, zombies, or anything else in a post-apocalyptic world, you have the same wrong opinion that almost every player I spoke with had. It is technically about the post-apocalyptic world in some undefined eastern European, Russia-like nation, but that is about as generic as it can be. There are no signs of the end of the world or a story to define it. There are just beaten-up buildings and bandits trying to kill you. That is it. Maybe I wasn’t as diligent in my research as I should have been when buying a game called “Deadside” so I assumed that it would have more to do with zombies or monsters or something in this post-apocalyptic world at the very least, not just bandits.

3.	I love that it took some overly complicated parts of a game like Dayz and simplified it for more normal use. Still, it is a rip-off of DayZ using similar assets and everything, but it just doesn’t function properly.

4.	While playing one day, it crashed, as it had been known to do, and I couldn’t rejoin my server. This continued for DAYS; to my knowledge, this official server never returned online. So, I had to start over on a new server because the server just disappeared.

5.	The game can be fun, but with glitches and issues against you already, they updated the AI to become ninjas. When you die, you have a finite amount of time to recover your equipment or lose it. You also have a finite amount of deaths before your body despawns and you lose it. So basically, you will never keep gear because it will be lost due to death or glitches keeping you from recovering it.

TL;DR
	Buy something else or wait until they maybe fix things with 5.0 but don’t expect them to fix the stuff that actually matters.

Deadside is if Tarkov and SCUM had a baby, but came out better than both the parents. It features some interesting game aspects and nice moments, but the general consensus of the game mostly revolves around looting and shooting. Most the time, you're traversing across the giant hills on foot since there are no vehicles, going after non-randomized events that are based on specific locations and very repeatable.

The AI is a very rough way of... ehhh, let's just put it that since the game is focused with AI in mind that can use guns and other weapons, it's not very fleshed out and balanced for the player from getting silently shot 200m away without a clue to where it came from.

The games overall future hope is there, but more content and fleshed out features need to start making an appearance before it becomes another one of those early access games that's not worth it.

I have 6.6 hours in the game, so far.  All I seem to be able to do is die.  I think this game has promise, but right now it isn't worth it even if it were free.  My friends will never play this game.  I do salute the devs for creating what they have so far, BUT...

Things that need fixing :
1) difficulty level needs to be a setting.
2) AI NPCs need to act *real*, not like 13 year old console kiddies who haven't entered puberty yet.  Real combat is not bunny hopping and running back and forth every second.
3) Seriously?  Where is the food and water?  Either get rid of that, or make the food and water more accessible.
4) 1 second breath hold?  That's stupid and unrealistic.  I'm old and I can hold my breath 30 seconds while aiming, from any position.
5) NPC accuracy is unrealistic.
6) I like that you can run forever without having a stamina effect.
7) I don't care about base building, but if I did, I'd want more resources or someway to manipulate the environment to get the resources needed.
8) players should start with more than a knife, because the knife is useless in combat.
9) Maybe save games could be implemented so you don't lose all your progress when you die.

I'll update as I go along.  I am "recommending" based upon what the game *could* become, not what it is right now, a giant bowl of frustration.

The only way I can describe this game is to bring up other games. If you've ever played DayZ/SCUM/ArmA Exile/survival base-building game #34678, and cringe at the thought of how crippling emotionally it is when you lose all of your stuff, then this game might be the solution you've been looking for. It definitely was for me.

     Deadside is an open world/basebuilding/survival game that trims all the fat off of the genre and leaves mostly just the fun parts of these games. Most major towns are respawn points, and you can craft and place down respawn beacons(with small limits like no  safezones) for yourself. Weapons are easy to come by. AI is cheesable even solo, and the map is big enough that you aren't getting smoked in the rear constantly by 16 yr old Tanner and his gaggle of fraternity fuckbois. The TTK(time to kill) is very short, almost Tarkov-esque without the non-pen bullet spongyness. A naked freshie with a shotgun can easily solo a 2-man group and even 3-man if they are occupied with mission AI.

     Randomly generated missions keep you on that dopamine drip with "lootboxes" that drop good weapons/meds/food/building supplies. AI is laser accurate when they are military bots, but cover and peeking do a really good job of mitigating this. All in all most missions are soloable if you have experience with jiggle peeking and repositioning.

YOU CAN NOT BE RAIDED WHILE OFFLINE (thank God)

     Gone are the days of logging in to an empty base. When players kill you, there is a 20% chance you will drop a "raid token". This token will expire and can't be hoarded, but once activated will show the "general" location of your base on the map to all players and at that point becomes raidable. The only way to get raided is to die to other players and even then its only a 20% chance each time you die. You can however die, ragequit, and then wake up to an empty base b/c you werent there to defend, when they popped the token. (whoops, happened to me RIP first base)

     Again, this is just DayZ/SCUM, but its actually fun. Downtime spent running and building are greatly minimized to keep you doing the fun stuff. You even get a run speed buff from being above 89 food/water!

     The developers did a really good job of capturing that old ArmA Wasteland feeling, but making it way more accessible to "gamer dads" or people who don't want to stare at grass for 3 hours while running somewhere for a can of peaches.

     This game makes open world survival actually fun, and capitalizes on making the player feel good about each gun they pick up, building piece they put down, and kill they bag. Nothing takes extraneous amounts of time. Death isn't a big deal. Hell, even losing your base isnt a big deal b/c you can solo missions with a shotgun that have the best loot as the reward.

     A fun DayZ/SCUM that trims all the "funk" from the gameplay model, and focuses on getting the player into whats fun and important. Getting loot and killing players or AI.

CONS
-No zombies (a PRO for me honestly)
-Gunplay can be wonky like holding breath after shift-sprinting too fast will cause you to re-enter "walk" 
   mode instead of just ADS'ing like you want it to.
-AI can be bullshit but the harder ones are supposed to be b/c the loot is phenomenal.
-This game is harsh on solos when it comes to PVP, but if you are good at PVP, it can be as much of an 
   adrenaline rush as Tarkov/DayZ fighting and winning against a 2-3 man group.
-I wouldn't say the game "needs more content", b/c im having a blast playing it regardless, but it definitely 
   could use more guns/attachments/loot types/points of interest. The PVP is what I stay to play for, but I 
   would love to see a wider variety of tools to kill people and AI with.
-Supporter pack gives skins which sends the wrong message to people. The game doesn't MTX skins at all. 
   The skins in game you can just paint onto your clothes using a workbench and it costs no materials at all, and there are default in-game camos that make more sense and are more concealing than the supporter pack ones.
- The map doesn't let you zoom in far enough, so examining terrain features and building up close on your map is not even possible. Relying on third-party maps is a must if you want to know where the good loot spawns. This should really be addressed by the devs. I should be able to look at the map closely, see a group of buildings that aren't marked as a "town" or "POI" and realize I've found an unmarked area that might just be ripe for looting. You get robbed of the ability to use these skills by the unzoomable map that lacks alot of terrain detail.

The PVE experience is lacklustre with the same type of missions every single time. Everything else is just a grind. Where are the animals as well? That's missing other than ducks. They didn't even introduce lights or torch + fire for bases. You can only light up campfires if you're cooking.

There is also no real story. Another similar game I used to play had proper animals and vehicles, as well as a story. The only reason why I even play this game is because the gunplay and movement system is a bit better.
I'm hoping to come back to this game after I confirm the devs include more QOL features.

fantastic game, mix of DayZ, Rust and H1Z1. Gun sway and optimization is the only thing I would complain about, as well as scarcity of food. But at the end of the day, when the game works, the game works. The expert level camps are actually hard and the gun sway makes you think twice and plan out your attacks before you make your move. If they optimized the game better, it would be much more enjoyable. When you go into big areas sometimes theres extreme frame drops even on powerful machines, it makes gunfights unplayable. Overall though, I believe that this is a good game with good potential. The devs are constantly updating it and the community is growing. This will be a fantastic game if it keeps receiving the amount of support it has been receiving.

[h1] Rust mixed with Tarkov. [/h1] 
That title can summarise half this game, if you love the constant action of Tarkov mixed with the elements survival elements of Rust, you'll also love this game, there is little to no handholding and for an early access game, this is amazingly underwhelmed with bugs. The supporter DLC is considered to be 'overpowered,' but as someone who has played with it, and without it, it makes little to no changes in the game, this game is entirely dependant on your skill, you can take out someone who's fully kitted with a pistol if you're good enough, the game is incredibly unfair, but that's what makes taking out the insane enemy AI at a helicrash or a elite level base raid so fun, the satisfaction that comes out of it. I look forwards to see the progress the developers make on this game, and heavily recommend you to buy the game so I can see you in the community.

Pros:
-Game looks nice
-Game runs well (for me at least)
-Weapons feel decent
-Base building system is solid and will probably become better in the future
-Events are a fun way to draw players to certain areas for loot
-I haven't seen any cheaters yet

Neutrals:
-Loot is fairly easy to acquire which is a pro and a con because for a game that calls itself hardcore i shouldn't really be finding myself with end game gear in 4-5 hours of playing when i really don't know what i'm doing.

Cons:
-No vehicles as of yet, map is fairly large and will only get bigger and running gets boring fast
-AI is stupid and can be meta gamed fairly easily once you learn how to deal with them, at the same time they are overpowered and will shoot you through bushes, trees, etc and sometimes just absolutely fuck you up, considering they are the main enemy in the world they definitely need to be worked on.
-Game has a very small player base right now, its not hard to find a server with players but at the same time your options are limited, especially if you are from Australia like myself.
-3rd person camera option is a pet peeve for me in these games, you can just play on 1st person camera servers but i don't have the luxury of both that and a solid player count on a server in OCE.

Overall, game is fun, as long as development and becomes more polished i think the game has a chance of success in the open world market.

Great game with a lot of potential. As it stands as of 17-Nov-2022, Deadside plays well for an open world PvPvE survival shooter. There's enough to do and nuanced things to discover that the game will keep you occupied for well worth the current 20$ price tag. Plenty of intense mil-sim like battles between AI and or other Deadsiders. Close quarters fighting in bunkers or well-timed marksman shots at 200m in mountain terrain are very rewarding. Base building is simplistic but deep enough to spend hours crafting a perfect fortress to store your scavenged spoils. Missions keep the game interesting with risk reward choices. Custom camo builds, a very welcome theme to the game keeping a realistic vibe. No hot pink bunny suits with carrot guns hoping through the woods here. Duck hunting! Hunt and scavenge for survival items to stay alive. The dev team genuinely listens to feedback and is engaging with community to make the best game they can.

No game is without fault. Please bear in mind that this game is in early access and many if not all the issues listed below are subject to change. That being said, where this game falls behind is in overall content, stability issues, some bugs, and generally things that come with an early access game. There is a lot to do in the game, but the map is very large. Travel time between events can be very drawn out which can be turn off for those looking for constant action. The AI can feel cheaty sometimes because their accuracy tends to be aim bot level or fresh on the internet noob. Could use general balancing for players’ spawns and default loadout. Many of these issues and more have been discussed by the dev team as in progress work.

Overall, this game is very fun and can only get better as it develops. I have high hopes for this game becoming a common game name to hear in the gaming community.

Everyone camps objectives by using base exploits or they wait in a bush with a sniper and steal all of your gear after you finish the quest for them since they are too bad at the game to survive against the brainless AI. Almost no loot variety compared to other games of the like, there's almost nothing worth looting in the random loot pool to make money from. There are no actual quests or missions in this game. Its just go to this location. Kill bots. Get reward. Very basic game with many flaws in the overall design choices with very few redeeming qualities.

After coming from DayZ, this is rough. 

Dying from dehydration right next to a well that very clearly has water in it, with a backpack full of alcoholic beverages that I can't drink for some reason, and only being 100 feet from a freshwater river.... is pretty bad to say the least. You can literally only drink soda starting off (which is what most players will experience).

Night time is brutally dark, which would be fine if you had any way of countering it at all. You have a lighter which provides a laughably small amount of light and would only give you away anyways. If it's night time and you don't have a base, just log out until morning so you don't go hungry or killed. AI can see fine at night. You cannot and there is nothing you can find or craft to change that to my knowledge. What fun.

I didn't want to complain about the gunfights as I like the realistic, slower fights, but it's an odd choice to have such slow shooting when fighting ai most of the time. It's too much change at once from the normal FPS and makes the gun play boil down to feeling just terrible in comparison to most shooters. Tarkov-style shooting can work in pvp settings. In PvE, it's meh.

The idea of this game isn't terrible but it clearly has such a small dev team behind it that it's hard to pretend there is much real content here. Hopefully over time they'll add enough mechanics to be more interesting.

Until then the shooting is relatively unskilled compared to better shooters, the scavenging is bland, the crafting is simple, and the survival is laughably bad. 

It isn't hard. It just isn't fun.
