I would like to preface this with saying that this game has a lot of potential to be fun and something that I could enjoy. However given its current state the game is poor for replayability and enjoyability. 

TLDR: Game has very little Replayabillity, AI is simple and annoying being either Dumb as Fuck or Botty as Fuck. The Gun Systems are annoying because of the Sway and the PvP is Defined by the M99 as the only gun worth using. 

PvP: The PvP element in this game feels like a game of see someone first and shooting them with your M99 first, The M99 is the primary sniper rifle in the game and can consistently 1 shot any targets at long ranges, this is important due to the ridiculous sway that all guns have, having to put multiple bullets down range becomes exceedingly harder after every shot and the longer you stay scoped, the only other weapon of interest is the UMP which has the most bullet damage of any full auto weapons too, making it the only answer for close quarters.

The Map Is Insanely large and is currently only a fraction of the size of what it's supposed to be, leading to long trips to and from areas, none of which are any different. The only real events in the game are a circle that highlights an area as an event of sorts, basically this spawns a bunch of AI (Which put a pin in that, we'll get to that later) The thing is that almost any one of them are the same. things like Heli Crashes are a bit more interesting in the fact that they can spawn anywhere. The problem is, this is the main gameplay loop between the game past PvP, very little else is available to do in the game. The thing is by having these as the only thing to do it gets very monotonous, even if they change this a bit would be nice and want to compare this to Rust, Rust has several PvE Encounters, With a Cargo shit and Circles the map but ultimately acts as a bunch of AIs, Cargo Rigs that have a bunch of AI, and a crate that calls in a bunch of Super Strong AI and then Launch with a M2 to fight for loot. and also a Heli that roams around the map that spawns occasionally. However I want to point out one thing about all of these above. They are all in support of PvP, Each one includes a PvE Function but afterwards the players need to defend their work, they are designed to support the main system of the game which is PvP. The problem is Deadside can't decide if it wants to be a huge mosh pit of Players or not, most servers can hold around 50, and with the map being so large it's hard for it to work, Cases work in the best way for this whereas events simply announce when they are done. Deadside can't seem to figure out how to add variety to its elements, nor can it decide if it wants those elements to support PvP functions of the game or Not. 

Guns, I'll go ahead and say that i can be fine with an early and basic system for developing a basic frame to get items, i can say that weapons in this game are complete and utter shit, When it comes to aiming there's this huge sway when you aim in for more that 3 seconds, it starts off a little but slowly exaggerates into huge swings, becoming unusable at nearly any range. which is a huge fucking problem when the AI, can Consistently shoot you at range, Scopes on Rifles make Zero fucking sense to use because the sway is massive, the recoil is going to cause this sway to exaggerate more then usual, if you want to run a AR-15 and slap a scope have fun shooting 2 shots, because thats all that you can realistically hit at range. But wait, isn't there a hold breath function, Yes and it's also shit, Its permanently bound to sprinting, meaning that if your are moving congrats your actually going to run instead of aim down sights, whats that your stopping to move to make a shot but your still slightly moving, Wrong your sprinting again. its so fucking annoying and it never feels like it actually helps too. But don't worry even though it's hard for you so use a rifle at long ranges the AI has no Problem perfectly tracing you and spray an ak in burst of 4 to hit you once atleast and can perfectly trace you,

This game simply isnt fun with the AI at the current stand point, They are ethir so little of a threat that you can walk away or so much of one that you cant even run away, i feel like its sometimes impossible to simply take a heli crash from these fucks who are wearing any armor usual with a default Iron AK47 and RPK who can 3 shot me at fucking 200 meters out, yet i struggle to hold a fucking Scar and hit shots consitently with an acog attached to it. It's pointless because the AI is dumber than a brick or Botty as an aimbot. Not to point out but these bots at long range sometimes take more shots that the player does, An RPK can 3 Shot me Wearing the best armor in the game, yet they also take 3 shots wear there fucking fatigues. 

Meds in the game are in abundance and dont do shit, PainKillers and Med sticks are the only good medications in the game and both require you to have Water and Food on hand to heal yourself, Bandages and wrapping exist but are more of a suggestion then anything, they heal minimal amounts over long periods. You can easily get wraps by tearing clothing which is going to be in abundance, and you can easily get the Alcohol to make sterilized rags which are “Better” But wont feel any different, this turns into gunfight with AI you just holding an angle Killing the ones that come through it, though you'll inevitably will get shot, and hope that it's not a mosin because those will one shot you regardless of armor, and then you'll sit in a corner praying that more dont come as you spam your 30 Rags on to your arm and slowly watch the number 30 crawl up to 100, Its meant to make fights tense with AI because you need to get Money to Buy Painkillers or Med Sticks later. But it really just makes fights longer and tedious. In the case of PainKillers you're just going to take 2 to get to max and then shove 3 cokes down your thoughts to make sure that you can take another 2 pain killers laters, it's faster but requires you to have more food which takes up already precious slots in your hotbar. However the cost of them is non-existent as the economy in this game is simple and you can easily rack up several hundreds of thousands of cash. 

All in all the game is fine as an early access, however the problems with me fighting the guns, me sprint when i'm trying to aim a gun, and the AI being able to trace me perfectly through wooded forests and shoot me at long ranges with Irons makes in extremely hard to me to enjoy the game

This is a great game if you enjoy decent gunplay, realistic ttk, co-op or pvp shooters.  I have loved each update as the game becomes more polished and continues to grow.  If you like survival games, but not a fan of when those games that take the survival aspect too far turning it into a chore, this is a good choice.  Think of it more as a shooter with survival elements.  Granted once you get the gameplay loop down, it can get boring, it is still in development after all.  Often referred to as Dayz/Tarkov LITE.  There is base building and a fantastic base raiding system that allows you to log off the game in peace as people can only get a chance to raid your base when you are online.  There are no vehicles on this fairly large map as of yet, but once you get your bearings and paths you want to run down, traveling isn't really as big of a hassle as some people make it out to be.

Devs are slow to update and do not keep to their own roadmap.  Promised features are constantly delayed.  They're entire FAQ on their Discord can be summed up as "thats a really cool feature but its really hard to implement.  if we ever did implement it, we'd likely strip it of X features and even then theres no promise we will add it".   Seriously.  Their defense for not having female characters is basically "this would mean we'd have to design more clothes and thats a lot of work so no".  If you try to criticize anything they flip out and start comparing themselves to Star Citizen for you expecting actual content.

The game is seriously lacking content.  End game can be reached in about 2 days.  Content add ons are sparse and few.  The "Halloween Event" is just giving a bunch of NPCS hockey masks(that cant be sold and are lower protection than the good gear).  The boat update has been pushed back twice now and is 2 months behind schedule.  Their reason?  It causes high population servers(50+) to crash.  But you'd be hard pressed to even find a server with more than 10 people playing.

Overall, this game is NOT a survival sim.  It is a first person shooter with some survival elements.  The core of the gameplay is expected to come from PvP and outside of that, the game is a desert.  If you want to play COD with hunger and limited base building, then this game is alright.  But if youre looking for a survival sim, this game is absolutely not that.  Escape From Tarkov or DayZ are much better options.

Scroll to bottom for Pros/Cons and TLDR.

Before I start I want to say that Deadside is by no means a *bad* game, it's just a very very mediocre one. The graphics are great and the weapon sounds and animations are pretty good, but thats really all I can pat the game on the back for, overall it's just a very "meh" game, it doesn't really have anything unique about it, you'd get the essentially same experience if you played in an Arma 2 DayZ server with the zombies turned off, with the only real difference being that DayZ has WAY more content and things to do. PvE is very boring as you are fighting the same AI Hobos and soldiers that randomly spawn on the roads or at event points, their difficulty ranging from "A sack of flower would put up a better fight" to "You've just been killed from 100m away through thick bushes and trees by the aimbot tier AI who's only gun is a sawn off shotgun from 70 Years ago". Speaking of shotguns, the gun balance is very frustrating, and shotguns are ridiculously OP even at medium range, whereas a player/AI can soak up 10 rounds out of an AK at close range and still have enough health to gank you in 1 shot with grandpappy's double barrel despite wearing heavy body armor and a steel helmet, the game is very broken in that regard and once you get your hands on a good shotgun you don't really need anything else, and shotguns spawn EVERYWHERE. PvE is bad enough but PvP is even worse.

The comabt isn't the only issue, the lack of loot is aswell, if you are in a moderately populated server then have fun starving to death because every house will be so picked clean of food you'd think you were in a 3rd world country during the 80s. And to add insult to injury the devs have recently removed the ability to buy food in safezones, why might you ask? Well thats because they have added ducks to hunt... Ducks that I have only seen twice and both times have glitched out of existence upon hitting the ground after being shot. So good luck with that.

Though to give credit where it's due that is one of the only bugs I've encountered, the other one being so increadibly frustrating that I've had it happen twice and the last time it happened I uninstalled the game and started writing this review. The bug goes as follows: If you decide you are done playing for the night and disconnect in the wrong place, the next time you log in there is a chance that you have done so in an area that regularly spawns hobos, so when you eventually when you try to rejoin, the AI hobos will kill your character before the loading screen even finishes, meaning that once you are in game you cannot more or even respawn like when you normally die, this forces you to disconnect from the server, wait, and then rejoin a couple times till the game decides you are allowed to be alive again, only to find that because you disconnected before recovering your body, the game despawned it, meaning any loot that was on your body is now gone forever. I lost 10ish hours worth of loot grind to this and there is nothing I can do but start the grind all over again.

Honestly that alone is all you should need to know, I'm not even gonna go into detail on how dumb and frustrating the base system grind is, because the limits on where you can actually place a base are so needlessly restrictive, that I had to wander around for over 2 hours to find a spot to place mine (Which was in the middle of nowhere, a good 10min walk from anywhere notable btw), and by that point I was too annoyed to even care about building a base at that point and just wandered back to civilization instead.

So yeah.

TL;DR: 5/10 game, really not worth the money in my opinion due to the issues I encountered, just buy DayZ instead, but hey, there are worse games to spend money on I guess.

I have to change my review of this game. It started as a game that played similar to a lot of the survival games out there. Where this game set itself apart was it was geared more towards PvP than survival. This was refreshing as compared to games like DayZ or Rust where harsher survival mechanics and building requirements. Although I do play both of those games, I enjoyed the differences Deadside had. However, in the last 3 or 4 updates the devs have been changing the game to be more like the others previously mentioned. They have taken a games that was fun to play and made it so grindy it's just not worth the effort. The game does have high quality graphics and others factors that still make it enjoyable. But, if the devs are pulling away from the games originality that set it apart from the rest, I cannot recommend this game at this time.

My thumbs down review is only a temporary one. This game has serious potential.
Right now, the whole thing is deeeeeeeply janky. 
All my experience is on PVE servers, fwiw:
  - AI bots are both brainless and godlike. Their pathing generally sucks so their aiming ability has been pumped through the roof.  Sometimes the bots will act the way you'd expect, but then you'll run into baddies that require multiple (5+) headshots to take down and have instant-reflex laser-beam accuracy.
 - You can easily lose all of the stuff on your body to any number of bugs or overly punishing mechanics. Sometimes your corpse won't be there when you get back to it (even when you make it in time). Sometimes your corpse will float on water (currently intended because you CANNOT dive beneath the water's surface) but other times your corpse will be underneath the water's surface so you can't actually retrieve your stuff. No, there is no recourse for this.
 - The places where you respawn after dying are also places where baddies tend to spawn, which means it's pretty common to respawn in the middle of a group of hostiles while you're armed with a knife and they've all got shotguns. You can usually outrun them, but not always.
 - Many systems in the game are not properly explained anywhere. For example, if you manage to grab a "case," which is a reasonably difficult thing to get your hands on, you have to immediately take it to a trader to gain any benefit from it. If, for example, you happen to lose your internet connection and have to log back into the game before you've had a chance to sell the case, it's removed from your inventory and you don't get the benefit of that item.
 - Tooltips are not at all informative. Clothing items, weapons, etc., none of them will tell you stats beyond required ammunition or irrelevant flavor text. Want to know the difference between one AK variant and another? You're reliant on the (fairly sparse) wiki. Some people may appreciate the "realism" of not having reliable information. I'm not one of those people.
 - Many in-game items have no use, or only a single use, but are so widely available that you may be led to believe those items are fairly important or otherwise valuable. Polyethylene, car batteries, and many other items are only useful for a single crafting recipe that you'll only ever need to make once. Some of them can't even be sold to vendors for cash. Other items have no particular in-game use at all. Spark plugs and machine oil, for example, have no current use and therefore can only be sold to vendors. Again, though, tooltips provide no useful information.
 - Base building is a humongous pain in the ass, but not for any constructive reason. You have to chop wood to build most things, but that's the only resource you can harvest. Anything else has to be found in the environment somehow. Sheet metal, for example, is required in order to build a number of things, but can only be reliably found in one or two locations. Referring back to polyethylene, though, despite only needing that for one recipe, you can find that almost anywhere.
 - In order to even build a base in the first place, you have to find a spot to place a claim. However, the rules for placing a land claim are not spelled out anywhere in game, so you end up just wandering aimlessly around the map, staring at your little plywood sign, waiting for it to turn from red to green. The game provides basically zero guidance on this process and it's easy to become discouraged and feel as if there's nowhere to actually set down a land claim.
 - Travel time in this game is horrendous. The map is WAYYYYY too big and too sparsely populated, such that it takes an excruciatingly long and boring time to make it from point A to point B. I recommend watching youtube videos or something in the background as you make your way between points of interest. 

Ultimately, this game has a lot of potential but it isn't anywhere near to being a finished product. It's an early access title, sure, but there's a lot yet to finish up before I can recommend this title to most people.

Absolutely love this game. Played many of the other popular survival games. Deadside is the only one to have a good balance between crafting, survival, and gunplay. Really fun to play. Bots are challenging. Updates come out on a regular basis. Game looks great. The base raiding system is fair to everyone. All very well done. 

Something I personally would like to see added is a system for distributing loot more fairly after mission/convoy completion and preventing people from stealing the loot/case. The game would look at who has killed the most bots during the mission and gives that player access to the loot/case before the other players, maybe a 30-60 second window to go through the loot or pick up the case before it's opened to everyone. 

Can't wait to see what the future holds for this game. If there was a second supporter pack available I would definitely consider purchasing it.

Edit: Almost 600 hours in to this game.  Duck hunting has been added. Would like to see other survival elements added as well. Still enjoying the game.

Amazing game, I'm big into MMO Survival games and I'm glad my lad told me about this game at the bar. First reaction went to a DayZ feel off of the graphics, movement and the genuine feel of the game in all. Then slowly became more of a Tarkov feel with the scav runs and missions, when in all this game is in a new realm of MMO Survival. I was hesitant with buying the game at first but started doing my own research and background of the game and the dev team, really hearing their story throughout YT and Twitch streams. With that research I have found that this dev team is really trying to not only show their fans but the genre in MMO Survival that they care about their product, which you can see in multiple updates/ patch notes since launch. With each update adding more life and pumping more potential into Deadside. As of right now I only have 17 hours into the game and will most likely be putting 1k plus into the game. However, I did spend the better half of 4 days really looking into this game because the genre in MMO Survival as a hole can get these games pumped out and die off so quickly because the numbers go low to Total Online Player, or simply a dev team that didn't put as much time in it to make the game better. As for Deadside, this is a game you really don't want to miss out on.

Not been so disappointed in a game mechanic like Deadside for a while.

To put it simply I was quite enjoying this game until I found out when someone dies or a group dies they can just respawn in the village where they died and just run straight back. Not sure how the devs thought that was a good idea.

If the thought of another player being able to fight you 2-3 times before you finally stop them coming back annoys you don't play this game. I was trying to solo build a base and its near impossible. You need about 500 nails to build a 2x2 but ontop of that, if a person finds you mid build you may experience what I just had.

You kill a trio trying to fight you, they all respawn in the village 600m away, loot guns and come back to fight you again. Luckily you kill them all again but then they respawn in the village 700m away. Then unsurprisingly you die in the final wave.

Keep in mind they were able to send 9 bodies to fight me in the span of 10 minutes. I wouldn't touch this game unless they added a mechanic where you aren't able to spawn where you just died.

This game is like throwing Arma 3, Pubg, Stalker, Tarkov and Rust inside a blender, and getting something that resembles none of the mentioned. It's its own thing, and that's good. My rating: 5/10

* I'm going to error on the side of caution and give this game a thumb's down for now as it is another open-world survival/shooter such as; Mistreated, DayZ, Last Day survival, and Romero's aftermath, with nothing unique to set it apart from the mix. Being very similar to the latter with 2 safe zones in which you can store loot and money found out in the world or gathered through trading at said safe zones and a very rudimentary crafting system. PvP is decent with 20 guns and 4 melee weapons along with 2 types of grenades across a medium-sized map, however, the movement across said map and the weapons are in need of a severe overhaul with inertia based momentum to knives being deadlier than a shotgun. Aside from the odd bug or two game play is pretty straight forward spawn, loot, kill, sell, repeat with a death or two thrown in the mix, that's it there's not much else to it. There is a basic base building mechanic but I didn't find a need to build one as each safe zone can store your loot and money, sadly storage is not linked together between the two safe zones, so I would pick one and stick to it if you die to keep spawn cycling till you spawn near the one you prefer (the South one seems more fleshed out IMO). I will continue to play periodically with friends and follow this game to see how this game changes and what it does to set itself apart from the rest.

This is probably the last DayZ clone that I'm ever going to play and here's why, starting with the Pros 1st cause there are some:
-Very nice graphics
-Super engaging gun play
-Ok-ish stealth mechanics
-Good lootdrop table all around - not too much, not too little
-Very fun experience IF you find the right people to play with( this will make a comeback on the opposite spectrum in the Cons section)
-Pretty basic and easy to learn gameplay curve - survive, get loot, build a base, get more loot, kill some players if that's your thing or if necessary, go to the bunker and feel good about this achievement.

Now the Cons:
Since this is a DayZ clone, you can expect that some big part of the community is made out of the same kind of people( mostly underage individuals ) that are salty when they loose stuff/get killed repeatedly by better players with more attention to their surroundings, that will call you a cheater for doing so and even get you GAME BANNED, not server banned, just for being better(Yes, the entire analyses process is a bad joke and maybe has something to do with closer relations between the one that got you reported and the person that manually got you banned).
It is generally better to go play in a server where you know people beforehand so you'll have the most fun;
from personal experience playing with or against randoms became boring at some point and then again, you can make new buddies but that's a rare occasion in this game.
Pro tip: If you're from EU, save yourself the trouble and avoid the Official servers.
Apart from the toxic side of the community, this is a russian made game with a dev team of around 5 people, a game which has been in early access since April of 2020 so yeah, take what you will of that information.
Other small cons:
-The environment is not very realistic, the trees don't fall to the ground when you chop them for wood
 ->there is no option to forage for mushrooms for food or even drink water from rivers
-There is no prone position option which could have a good side as well but this game is pretty hardcore at times so it would be useful to add one in the future
-No easy way to report players for ACTUALLY cheating or other toxic/inappropriate behavior, you have to open a ticket the old fashioned way
-Generally a mediocre game that doesn't bring anything special to the table but mostly takes away from it but that's maybe just due to the lack of experience on the dev's part.

I really hope that Deadside will change for the better in the foreseeable future though I will not be surprised if it won't, to only then get overshadowed by bigger and more ambitious projects made by more experienced people AND with a better and more welcoming community behind it. Best of the luck to the devs on making the most out of this project!

Deadside is far from complete and is still in Early Access keep that in mind. I feel a lot of negative reviewers expect too much from so little that is available. The game DOES have bugs/exploits and may lack some fundamental content (end game, story, etc.) but does deliver on what it is - a survival game. Only main issue of mine in-game is the sound design. It's God Awful. I've played half my hours solo and the other half in a squad and I'd definitely recommend playing with friends. Solo play is satisfying once you understand how the game works. 

Devs have been transparent so far with the community and have released several patches and updates since launch addressing some concerns of the players. This is good, Keep it up and great survival game could be on the horizon. Just don't start working on useless stuff before fixes and optimizations like most other survival devs do. Gl out there

Compensa comprar agora por dois motivos: está barato e apoia os desenvolvedores.

Sobre o jogo em si, tá na cara que vai ser um grande nome do gênero. Mas ainda está muito cru, falta muita coisa ainda.
Não me entendam errado, a jogabilidade já está muito boa! E os recursos disponíveis são muito bem feitos (construção de bases, mecânica das armas, etc.). Mas no atual estágio ele se torna repetitivo até ficar monótono. Compra, joga pra conhecer e dê tempo ao tempo. A Dead Pixel fechou parceria com a Tiny Build ano passado, o que traz credibilidade e muita pro projeto. E eu quero acreditar que, vendo os jogos da Tiny Build, esse jogo vai trazer inovações mais do que merecidas/necessárias pra esse gênero que está em morte cerebral faz algum tempo.

Eu acho que Deadside tem um potencial enorme, coisa de virar WoW dos jogos de sobrevivência mesmo. E os elementos de (pseudo) RPG já estão presentes no jogo! Só de ver um jogo desse gênero com NPCs (não só bots inimigos) já me deixa entusiasmado. Espero que os devs caprichem no quesito customização de personagem e variedade de itens, coisa que o Tarkov faz muito bem. 

Legal ver que o anúncio de Stalker 2 remexeu um pouco as coisas no gênero "zone-like". 
Espero que este seja um jogo de sobrevivência que dê amor tanto pra quem joga em galera, quanto pros lobos solitários.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

World: The world is a great medium well balance world with small towns and some good POI’s with different tiers of loot. Some trees on the map still float about 1m above the ground, but I found only a few in the world (most on slope areas). About animals *see Survival Elements below.

Weather: I think a weather system would have worked great, it will add to the atmosphere, at the moment it is always clear skies. The day/night cycle works well.

In game Map: The in game map is great, the function of adding multiple marker points on the map to track your user waypoinst/POI's are great, wish every game had it. 

The character: The character looks great, the clothes are nice at the moment, when climbing over objects the character seems to stay on top of the object until you move forward and not just leaping over. You can climb through windows that are very nice for different room access if someone is already in a house building etc. You can set the FOV so that makes the First Person view easier to manage and with a free look button to view realistic angles by moving your neck. Biggest thing I miss in this game regarding the character is to prone (There is no prone), making stealth approaches very difficult. Jumping while running seems like you can’t jump far while running.

Sound: The world sound is nice, for example you can hear the humming noise of a Transmission Tower (Electricity Pylon). But there is an ambient noise that sounds like footsteps, and then you look around and see nothing, you can hear squirrels or small animals in the vegetation which seems realistic. The normal walking in game seems a little bit loud to sneak onto someone. Also making stealth approaches difficult.

Base Building: The base building is still basic but I like it, I think in future updates the base building will be great. You need an axe, saw and hammer to start your build, I think that makes it a bit more realistic and with a team effort you will have a base in no time. (Make sure someone is on guard while you build).Biggest thing that needs to be done on the base building side is for the clan/squad to access the base while the clan/squad leader is offline. 

Survival Elements: You can drink sodas and eat canned foods; I would like to see animals in the world. Maybe to hunt them, or have some fruit trees around to harvest from, it will make the survival aspect easier to manage than to go to the trader and keep on buying food and sodas, and here and there you can find soda and food in houses etc. The dam should be accessible for drinking, maybe have a water container to retrieve the water. (Well this is just a suggestion).

The NPC’s: They come in variety and some are more difficult than others, but I must say they are just perfect.

The Weapons: From Pistols, shotguns, sub machine guns, assault rifles to sniper rifles. A good variety with mod options, on the mod side I would like to see a hunting scope for some of the rifles, and some other new attachments. But we need to wait and see.

The missions: The missions are fun, they also come in different difficulty so that gives you a choice to approach it or not. I would like to see different scenarios of missions; maybe in the future they will add it.

Safe Zone and Traders: There are two safe zones, each with two traders. One where you can buy weapons and gear and other one where you can buy food/soda, tools etc. You can sell looted items to buy new gear etc. There you can also talk to your enemies or friends about what happened in the field.

The Servers: I Personally think the players need access to the server files to host their own servers in the country they reside, playing on a ping of +-200ms with or against players with a ping of 10ms is just unfair but debateable. Not all countries have an Official Server, so consider before you buy, just in case it might be unplayable with excessive high ping. At the moment you need to rent a server but the server will still be hosted elsewhere. A lot of server lags at the moment but I saw the Developers are working on it. 

Buy it/don’t buy it: The game is still early access and has only been released on the 14th Arpil 2020, it is still very new. It is affordable and it comes with a support pack for information on the store page https://store.steampowered.com/app/895400/Deadside/
I will say it is a must buy, the developers are working around the clock to fix the small bugs, they are very interactive with the players and they keep them up to date with what is happening. For a small developer group they have done very well and I think the launch was overwhelming and unsuspected. I see great things for this game. Edit: I am editing this part, on the release I felt that the developers are doing a good job, at the moment they are doing a good job by keeping a selective player base happy and content, on the other hand if you not close to a server you will experience a high ping and will battle to play due to rubberbanding.

Edit: "on the other hand if you not close to a server you will experience a high ping and will battle to play due to rubberbanding." I will have to say, I reinstalled this game after a couple of updates to see if the server issues are resolved, due to no local servers playing it makes it almost impossible. There is no change in ping which is understandable due to server location, but the rubberbanding is non existent, I do believe that when Tinybuild bought into Bad PIxel that they saw a lot of small things that can change, especially on the Server side of things. I am still hopeful for a local server but it is at least playable and the game that I was looking for.


Closing Comment: I will update this review as we go along.

PS. If I encounter and kill you, please forgive me as it is called Deadside for a reason.

Keep safe and enjoy.

I can't recommend this game in its current state but if some things were to change I'd consider playing this game again and removing this bad review below are my reasons for giving this review and potential solutions for these issues

more advanced AI: AI currently will stand out in the open and shoot at you even reload out in the open don't try to seek cover if they are in a building and hear you they will all come out of one doorway even if 5 of them are mowed down in front of them sometimes they will reload and stand right in front of you they don't try to flank you or act in an intelligent way to counteract you they'll just walk straight at you and shoot usually they will also bunch up in one big group I've entered missions before and had all 20 AI from the mission come out in one big cluster and kill me if the AI has an AK or any automatic weapon you're dead because they'll beam you on automatic and 1 shot takes a significant chunk of your health and to add insult to injury the AI has unlimited ammo so they can spray forever and there's nothing you can do about it I think this problem could be fixed by making the AI seek out cover when they take fire make it so they will try to flank the player and coordinate in a way that will support their teammates
current AI: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3NHyEB5bS44&ab_channel=KennPlaysDeadside
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=59aZY3KVPyE&ab_channel=Boose47
Vehicles: this is something that should have been in the game on release and the fact it's still not in after 2 years as of currently is ridiculous if you want to get anywhere in the map you have to run there the only saving grace about this is the fact that you have unlimited sprinting and there's an auto run key but this still takes a fair chunk of time around 10-20 minutes and this is going in a straight line combine this with missions that take place all over a map you can be running 5km to the objective just for the mission to end right when you get to it and then you gotta run 5km back which takes a fair chunk of time when a vehicle would resolve this issue it's also worth noting there are players who I've seen openly say they won't be playing the game again until they add vehicles which should be a major call for the developers to listen to their fan base

Developer priorities: the developers priorities are all over the place they should be working on simple things such as vehicles and better AI but they seem to want to work on things such as more realistic indoor gunshots, new camos, and improved bullet impact effects to name a few which is great and all and it is appreciated but it should be of higher priority to get vehicles sorted which is something that should've been present at launch and many have said they want to such a degree that they've stopped playing until they are implemented put in what the player base wants or those players will start looking elsewhere 

Servers:all servers appear to be hosted through gportal which wouldn't to such a big deal to me if it weren't for the fact that this is the only way to host your own game you can't host locally for single player and you can't do a small dedicated server for maybe 4-8 players in case you want to play with just your friends in PVE if you want to do that you either have to play in a public server or rent your own server which will run you at minimum $5.50 per month if you are hosting from US but you can go to the following link to check other prices the way I view it is I've already paid the price for the game if I want to play it on my own or with a small group of friends I shouldn't have to pay per month to host a private game for a small group of friends I get 20 people but for 4-8? plus with the fact we might not want to keep that server running 24/7 because we might wanna play something different? and I presume once we stop paying that server cost and it shuts down we lose everything so then we have to pay again and restart? that's not right we should be able to have a dedicated server which we can have free of charge which we don't have to worry about losing everything on because we didn't pay for said server
server pricing link: https://www.g-portal.com/us/en/order/step/one/deadside 
my solution to this problem is allow us to have a single player mode which will allow us to fiddle with settings and only be able to play solo and allow us to host dedicated servers possibly for a maximum player count of around 4-8 players 

Land Claiming: claiming land in this game to build on is way too restrictive it was to such an extent that I ended up running around for 10-15 minutes trying to find a place I could place my land claim the only solution I have for this is maybe consider loosening up the restrictions more but keep it so that people can't build right outside or in a safe zone and people can't block a road or wall off locations

Extra: from what I've seen from other reviews the devs seem to dislike when people leave bad reviews on their game allegedly doing such things as banning said player in a retaliatory manner in both the game and in their official discord the community is not much better they seem to be a bunch of yes men who approve of everything the developers do and if you raise any kind of issue you find with the game they will belittle you or defend the issue claiming it isn't an issue and it's very noticeable if you look at forum posts on places such as steam and reddit and some of the threads in their official discord as well as in the official discord in general

if they do end up banning me for giving them criticism and solutions to their problem I'll update this and if they work on the major issues that their game has I'll remove this review and maybe I'll consider recommending this but as it stands now this is what I've experienced and I can't recommend this to anyone try other games such as Rust, DayZ, and Scum

Ok so the game is most def still rough around the edges. Base building is still lackluster and if you play on official servers there's a good chance a cheater is camping middle of the map with an SVD at the top of a tower base. 

That being said, I have so much fun when I play it. Every update I hop back in and get another 20-30 hours in. I usually find a group of strangers and we team up and play for a few weeks. Fast travel is in the game now which helps a lot. Still can feel dead in some spots though. I prefer 1st person servers and if you can find a decent admin it can be a really awesome pvp/pve experience. 

For all of it's faults though, the gunplay is great. The looting system is great. The missions  (although repetitive and cheeseable once you figure them out) are still great too. And when you get a group running around getting into pvp battles throughout the day, it can feel even more satisfying than Tarkov for me. 

If the game keeps updating and progressing in the way it does, I really do think it'll be a staple survival shooter in the future.

Good middle ground of Dayz, Tarkov, and Rust. Early Access, so expect some things early access brings, but all in all, solid game for a great price. Bots pose a serious threat (sometimes feels like too much of a threat, F*** mosins) but good gun play, and missions always give something to do.

Essentially, Dayz x Tarkov. The game combines these two games very well. It is quite enjoyable, and with the newest updates making it even more so. I remember playing the game for the first time in early 2021 and it has come so far. Very impressed with the dev's commitment and work. Deadside still has some ways to go however, there is much room for improvement (things such as adding easier ways to traverse the vast landscape, fixing safe zone campers, improving current settlements with more life rather than expanding the overall map with abandoned POI's, etc). Nevertheless, I would definitely recommend Deadside, sometimes its easy to forget that the game is only in Early Access, so we judge it as a finished product but the fact remains, it is an Early Access game!

Lots of fun, it's like a faster DayZ but better. You can play PvP or have a more chill experience in PvE. I love the base building and raiding mechanic, which makes it so you can only get raided while actually being in game. I have high hopes for this game and the following updates. Excelente game! Ainda bruto por estar em early access, mas com enorme potencial. Trata-se de um shooter sandbox hardcore de sobrevivência. Morreu? Tem que buscar corpo. Diferente da maioria do gênero, esse não possui extração, mas safe zones com vendors e storage. Assim como um sistema de base building para você construir sua própria base, onde você pode respawnar e guardar seus itens. O sistema de sobrevivência é tranquilo, basicamente só gerenciar comida e bebida. O jogo possui servidores oficias e privados, PVP / PVE, visão em primeira ou terceira pessoa. Importante destacar que o mapa é grande e não possui fast travel, pelo menos um não tão acessível, então a bateção de perna é forte. Mas já foi confirmado que em breve teremos veículos, então é apenas um problema passageiro. Outro ponto forte do game é qualidade gráfica, não apenas os visuais que por si só são um elemento a parte (floresta, montanhas, rios), mas a própria a performance que não deixa a desejar em nada. Mesmo após umas 80h e com uma placa de vídeo mediana, o jogo segue rodando bem, sem nenhum crash que eu me lembre.

I dig this game. However, there isn't much to do atm beside shooty shoot and looty loot. Oh, and run, a lot, for there are no vehicles in the game yet. Two things to note: no stamina bar so you can sprint infinitely, and if you collect dog tags you can use them as a currency to travel betwixt safe zones, of which there are two - at least in the server I'm playing on. 

It's fun to collect gear and you only have to worry about hunger and thirst as far as survival goes. No sicknesses like in DayZ, atm anyway. I for one hope it remains that way. This game doesn't have zombies so we should be good on that front. 

I hope in the future the map gets at least a big city and another minor city. The villages are cool and feel lived in with some cool detail in the dacha models and vehicles, and the industrial areas are nice, too. However, to make the world seem more real and filled up, a city with apartment blocks, grocers, perhaps a soviet statue and some soviet mosaics, a city square, etc., would be awesome!! 

Another note: I have not played on a PvP server, nor have I played with the housing/building, so can't speak to those aspects of the game.

>Downloaded the game, decided to give it a shot.
>play for 36 minutes, kill a few fully kitted people & AI with a pistol I found in a house on a public official server
>decide I don't like it & submit refund
>receive email back from valve
>cannot receive refund on game you're game banned in
>play on Hell Let Loose with same anti-cheat
>no ban on HLL, but persists on Deadside

>MFW you get game bans locked to your steam account by upsetting admins by killing them while they're fully kitted.
Worst game on steam hands down, get better administration that doesn't rage when they get killed by a noob

EDIT: Ban was lifted. I am still leaving this negative review for the fact that false game bans like this ruins peoples reputations in communities, and gives thought that the person is lying, even in my case, which I was not. (anyone asking about the vac ban I have on file, which is invisible to those who dont have Steam inv manager, was from MW2, the original MW2, 12 years ago, when I was a child) I have no actual way of guaranteeing that it was admin based, but that was the only conceivable conclusion I came to given I played for 36 minutes only, and killed people that were kitted, to then soon after get a ban.

Devs; If you're going to put in an anti-cheat, make sure it actually works before implementation. The reason provided (which you can see in the comments) was "It looks like there was some kind of technical problem and when one of the cheats was detected, non-cheaters were banned as well", basically meaning SOMEONE in my game was cheating, and EVERYONE was punished because of it, instead of JUST the cheater. Sure, I was going to refund anyways, but the fact still remains. Fix the implementation so nobody ever has to go through what me and many other are going through currently.

This game has the right idea, just needs to execute on it.

I can only expect the game to improve and get better as time goes by and the players write honest and dedicated reviews for the Developers.

I would definitely recommend Deadside, especially over other games like Scum, PUBG, or Day Z. No wandering around for hours trying to get geared up. I would also recommend playing in private servers, not official ones. Less cheaters & hackers in private servers. Also I would rather play this game in PVE rather than PVP. PVE servers are generally very friendly, and helpful, especially for newbies. I have given loads of good gear away in this game for free. Because that's how I roll. You help me, I help you. I am running this game in full 4K on maximum settings. Just make sure you set vegetation to minimum for when the 'scavs' scatter into the wheat fields. It's less easy for them to hide. I have sunk nearly 400 hours into just one server on this game. Amazing game & the bullet/gun physics is mind-blowing & genuinely frightening when you get ambushed!

Finally having an actual grasp on this game I can write a review.  
9/10.

A very fun and promising survival game, definitely needs some more content and 
vehicles but of course, this is an early access game.

The character movement and gun play is amazing. Its really fun to get
use to the weapons, recoil, and attachments. The guns and skins look
incredible and its just all around very fun. 
*Recoil being updated soon as well*

The map is too big without vehicles, its an absolute running simulator from mission 
to mission. Glad they may be released before 2023

Base building system just got reworked and its a lot better, still missing
a lot of key building components but, its in the works. Limited storage 
is available which is kind of a bummer. (Only 6 storage bins allowed).

AI takes a little bit of time to get use to and learn the tricks to beating them.

How much like DAY-Z do you want this game to be?
Devs: Yes.

If you like that game, you should like this. I think they went a little hard on making this game as 1:1 with that game (Some stuff, feels like it was straight ripped) This means that instead of improving upon what the other game did, the implementation in deadside is near identical, clunkiness and all.  Animations, progress bars, the way your model looks, the first and 3rd, they even emulated the limitations of Bohemia's Arma 3 Engine inside Unreal Engine 4. I think this team is capable of taking what was good about that game and making it entirely new and polished - leaving the clunkiness behyind.  The UI is far improved in this game than it is in DAYZ, and it's not a frame rate chomper like the ARMA 3 engine.  That being said, I know this is early access but I hope the devs move in the direction of taking what worked with that game, and leaving behind the stuff that sucked about it.  You can see that game's fingerprints all over this game, from the way you look when free looking, to the animations, to the landscape, the buildings etc.

I would also like to be able to run and gun a little better so I didn't have to stop and shoot at these bots.  The aim just goes flying all over.  I get it, you can't run and ADS anyways, but there's a reason most ADS mechanics have you slow down, it's to make movement possible.

I think implementing a way to move while the inventory is open will help players sweep for items.

Game is absolute dogshit.  Initially I thought I had found a very good balanced raiding system, but when someone kills you there is a chance you drop a raid token and people have 1 hour to raid your base.  Let me clarify that, the entire fucking server can come and take your shit.  Died to someone who didn't even come raid my base, another 2 or 3 teams did. They used about 10 C4, destroyed all our locks which aren't easy or cheap to get.  The initial team that raided us had their own stalkers (best backpack in the game) and you can't stack backpacks.  We had 5 stalker backpacks in our base, and lost them all because again EVERYONE can come and loot your shit even if they haven't ran into you.

Spawn system is also so bad.  When we were getting raid, we killed about 3 people like 4 times over and over because they can just spawn instantly close to your base.  Not only that, but every single time they came back, they came back with full gear, so they were hacking if they could just keep spawning back in.  So not only do you have to deal with the normal hackers that have aimbots, you also have to deal with hackers who can just get all the loot they want and just harass you since you actually try to earn the things you have.

A vast majority of the community constantly keeps asking for the devs to change the game to the Tetris inventory system (similar to Escape From Tarkov).  But the devs have never even addressed this.  Haven't said whether they will or they won't.  Sorry but the way video games are right now, if you aren't a game developer that is listening to your community, what are you?

The game is kinda fun but there's way too much walking going on. There's no vehicles yet so you have to wonder around forever to go to events and loot stuff. You cant loot more than two guns at once unless you have the biggest backpack. The building system is very bad and claiming land to build on it is a real pain (took me more than 45min of walking around to be able to place down the claim). Looting is fun but you have to walk a lot and you cant loot much. The bots will aggro you from a distance without actually seing you and they will aimbot you to death quickly. You have to cheese them by waiting in corners and trying to glitch them. Overall, the ai in this game is very bad. The gunplay is a bit clunky too ... I would not recommend the game in it's current state. It's missing too much crucial features (vehicules, a real building system, good ai for the bots etc)

Not a bad game, community kinda sucks. I strongly recommend playing on a dead or low pop server for PVP and or even off hours to avoid the heavily geared players (full armour, rpk, mosin)  safe zone camping especially in the south safe zone. Will probably be a lot better when the map gets bigger and there are more safe zones so its harder for people to camp newbie areas. Also recommend trying out DayZ or SCUM on private servers with tweaked loot and settings as you are less likely to get camped or even run into full gear people in the newbie areas.

Also been on a few private servers that say they "deal" with safe zone campers or have rules to make it safer for new players, long story short they don't do anything, there's no admin on the server during peak times (NAE) and even with evidence (screenshots and vids) they won't do anything.
Just like PUBG and escape from tarkov but with far more hackers and far less optimization than both of them combined :)

The game is great, I've been missing games like this for a long time. The only problems that there are in this game are the AI and the lack of faster travel around the map which is expanded from time to time. It takes longer to get to an event location than it does to just clear it, and it is (in my opinion) one of the most boring things you have to do in order to get any loot. Adding vehicles to Deadside would be a big improvement, even one vehicle in the form of a rover that can be upgraded, such as the ability to store items in the trunk, better steering, traction, slight speed increases, and tank capacity and fuel consumption. Overall the game is great, it is constantly being improved. For an early access game, it is well done. I can recommend it to anyone who likes this type of game. It is, you can say, a child of DayZ and Escape from Tarkov.

Didn't expect much but pleasantly surprised! 
it strikes a good compromise between punishment, reward and action as I was never into looting and running for hours without getting into a fire fight ala Dayz. The npc's are better than devs with millions behind them like pubg where they make some aggressive plays on you at times and its a blast when you have 6 of them coming at you. The one shot kills they get are too common though and I haven't found a way to avoid it, eg. its got nothing to do with standing still for to long. You can auto run and get a drink without getting stuck on the first object you hit as well so yeh overall you can relax and enjoy a drink and a chat in between missions with some surprises along the way like running into a roaming convoy of npc's.

So far my biggest criticism is the big fps drops and regular stutters! 
If a game doesn't run smoothly then your on borrowed time in my book no matter how fast you put new content in. Overall I like that its a shooter you can play, get some excitement but not care about dying and have a laugh and chill...Oh and I like that there are a bunch of guns/upgrades you can only get in missions or by killing a player who got them from completing one.

I got it on special for $17 so in 3 days I have well and truly got value for money already :)

It's low-grade Rust meets Dayz minus a good bit of content.

Its as if they made the bulk of fundamentals FIRST (especially performance), to be followed by the bulk of content. I come from dumping over 2k hours into EFT over the last few years, so its nice to see the opposite of what they're doing applied to a dev cycle, however I 100% agree with the other reviews suggesting that this is really just a game coming out soon and you are buying a demo... aka the entire point of early access. 

No one is forcing you to buy; either enjoy messing around for <10 hours, or wait, its up to what $20 means to you.

Edit: Its been two years since I reviewed this and.... essentially no new content at all. No idea how they failed to just add to a pretty ok framework, but they've certainly failed.

I've played this for long enough to quit two separate times in different years due to lack of content and bad mechanics.
Cons
-Godly AI (They see you from a mile away and through objects. They will snipe you from over 100 meters away with a pistol or pre-aim your head while you take cover and pop you in 0.03 seconds when you stand up to fire.)
-Low amount of loot (Unless you find one of the few servers with x2-max loot enabled, the stock % of world loot in public servers will have you searching a dozen houses before you find ANYTHING and that thing you find will be maybe a few nails or plank of metal but you'll look forever for a gun.)
-Dying of boredom while running everywhere (The distances you run between places or from the edges of the map back to a safe zone will have you auto-running for so long that you will get bored because other than running into a cheap and annoying AI, there's nothing along the way other than more missions against brokenly strong AI. No animals to hunt for food or fear attacks from, no fun way to properly raid bases other than a 60minute window token) Which brings me to my last con.. 
-Server size vs map size (The game takes forever to run across but the servers only hold 50 people with a party limit of 5 people and this makes big clans impossible to form. It takes about 2.5 minutes to run 1km.. the game is currently around 35km large with plans to reach 225sq.km but player size is only projected to increase to 70-80? The map will always feel dead and over filled with AI!  Take what you like from this game and look for it in something else.
Until they add vehicles and not in a "headache to fix up and only use for 10 minutes" sort of way and increase server numbers to at least 150, this game will fizzle and close down. Lately it feels like there's only 1 guy working on the game while trying to portrait a larger team.
I have been searching for a true successor to H1Z1-Just Survive for years now and unfortunately, this isn't it.

Where the game is right now, it's not fun. The idea of having NPC's is great in theory but they crank the AI accuracy and aggro WAAAAAAAY too high. The gunplay is super clunky and you find yourself fighting with your character to properly peak a corner without it raising its gun up, or tryna hold your breath for a steady shot without the gun zooming back out of ADS. You get trapped in walls to a point where you have to die and run back to your body which is especially hard if you're in the middle of a mission as NPC aimbot 3000 will hit you almost every time with rifle fire (which is 50 damage per hit and they rack a shot every 2 seconds) Did I mention the AI can see you in pitch black darkness and hit you just as easily? Well they can and they do, every time.
    There are too many guns with too many different ammo types leaving you with a jigsaw puzzle of inventory junk until you find something that works with your loadout. I wouldn't mind the different guns if they could just keep it to maybe 3 to 4 ammo types but there are at least 3 ammo types for each class of gun aside from shotgun with a total of 5 classes for a whopping 12 ammo types that just sit in the inventory. The inventory clutter in this game is ridiculous.
    Building is a nightmare, like for real. You need specific items to build which makes sense but the drop rate of said items is slim to none especially if you got other players strolling through these same places and you can't craft them. materials are another issue, you need TONS of nails (low max stack making it an inventory issue again) and to find an axe which is set in the PRIMARY WEAPON SLOT, you gotta make a choice, ditch your gun, or build a base to store your gun, or just kill everyone and not die heading to a safe zone, easy enough. How are you gonna require so many logs for a scaffold and put 4 per max stack in your inventory? it's gonna take like 20 minutes to lay a scaffold, JUST ONE then you still gotta put up walls and ceiling, too much work to save the items you've been working to get, only to have someone run up on you mid build and drop you. The game relies heavily on having many people working with you because even for 2 people it's a big ask to have them drop their guns in trade for an axe and mule for building materials. Now they do have safe zone storage which gives you about 12 slots which does help, but these safe zones are decently far from eachother, so making a trek to a safe zone takes distance and time while players are stopping people going to safe zones, i see more gun play going on just outside the safe zones than most mission areas. 
    All in all the idea of this game is great and seeing it in the future I am hoping they address a lot of the issues mentioned as it is still early access and I keep tryna tell myself that while I continue to play but until then, it's a no from me chief.

They have already released micro-transactions for skins. The map is too open, with transport remaining painfully slow running everywhere. The AI is completely broken to the point where cheesing their mechanics to easily dispatch of them is always the optimal strategy. I love the gun-play and the economic mechanics of this game, but the pace of development is abysmal. Before I would have happily recommended it, even after release of the Supporter Pack. The latest addition of paid cosmetic DLC is too egregious for me to look past. In my opinion they simply have not delivered enough progress or meaningful changes to the most pressing issues that this game faces to be able to justify MTX at this point. It should be indicative to anyone looking to purchase this game now that these developers continue to lack the proper priorities. This game has gone and is going nowhere since I purchased it over 2 years ago. The AI is absurd, Base building is consistently buggy, rudimentary and just generally poorly implemented. The "Missions" are all just cut and paste in different locations - KIll all NPCs and loot your reward. There is absolutely no depth. Weapon/Armor skins existed in game and were the only thing to seek out once you had decent armor/guns, there is no reason not to continue to expand what you could obtain by playing the game. Clearly, they want additional revenue streams from an early access game that progresses at an absolute snails pace.  Cannot in good faith recommend it now that they are asking for additional $$$ for micro transactions.

I like what this game wants to do, but it's nowhere near being a "Tarkov Killer" or even a viable alternative yet.

There's definitely a few things I really like. It's nice that you can back out of pretty much any animation at any time. The forest sounds are really nice and help with the immersion. I like that the open world map shows missions and events on it, which helps drive player interaction and/or PvP. The UI is pretty straightforward and I was able to puzzle out how most things worked pretty quickly. It's nice that the AI isn't laser accurate, so between that and the longer than Tarkov TTK, you typically have time to react.

Unfortunately, there's a lot of negatives. The reload animations are feel less like a hardened survivor frantically reloading under stress and more like a slow paced tutorial on how to reload each weapon made by someone who is terrified of breaking the gun. There's also no tactical reloads, so every single reload has to go through the same extremely slow process. All of the animations feel slow and require you to watch every last frame of them for them to count instead of having small windows where you can do things like change weapons or shoot back.

There's an utter lack of inertia with the AI, so sniping is astoundingly difficult since the AI can change directions without losing any speed.  The AI also can see through most of the foliage in the game, so while they won't immediately laser you down, breaking line of sight to heal is difficult and results in a lot of deaths. There seems to also be some weirdness with hitboxes and hit registration, but I'm willing to admit that some of that might be user error. The AI also has no alert sounds, so your only warning that you've been spotted tends to be gunfire.

The map itself is around 25km square, which would be really cool with a fully populated 50+ person server, but it feels extremely empty otherwise. It's not unusual for me to have to spend several minutes running between points of interest. This wouldn't be a bad thing, but spending several minutes trudging across the map, followed by slowly clearing a mission and then being rewarded with the same lackluster loot that you've always been getting really kills the fun.

I really hope this game gets the love it deserves. I love the idea of a hardcore open world shooter, but I can't recommend this game until it gets some polish.

The gunplay in this game is just terrible. Your character weaves around like a drunk no matter what stance they're in and the "breath hold" option lasts like a quarter of a second and includes the period your character spends straightening up and moving the crosshair back to the center of the screen.

This isn't much an issue at short range, and in fact can spice things up by punishing panic fire.
At long range it's annoying but workable since you'll usually be using a high powered rifle and killing in one shot.
But 90% of the time you're gonna be fighting at mid range and you just WILL NOT be able to place accurate followup shots unless you're squinting through ironsights.

Literally no other game with shooting as the primary combat mechanic makes you deal with this crap. It's not "balanced" or "different" it's just idiotic.

I never leave reviews on steam, but this game will definitely be my first. Let me tell you, if you're coming from DayZ or Tarkov, this game hits the nail on the head. It's not TOO grindy, but there still some late game gear fear because some stuff is pretty hard to get, but you can spawn in and have a decent setup within 30 minutes or less. There are no diseases or gun degrading, unlike Dayz where you die from a common cold out of nowhere. You don't need to eat or drink constantly, but there is thirst and hunger. The crafting system just got rebuilt and is amazing. This game has lots of exciting pve / pvp. It honestly fits every style of player. Want to be a solo player who hoards and builds larges bases? you can do that. Want to be in a squad and pvp for loot and glory? you can also do that. The community is not toxic like rust. If you start the game anyone at safezone will hook you up with starter gear to get you going. I am a person who tends to lose interest in a game pretty quick, partially because ADHD and the such. This game literally has me excited to get on every single day. Absolutely love it. I'd easily pay AAA prices for this game. These devs actually know what they are doing too and have a very active discord and actively update the game.

I've left my review from a few years ago intact, but take it with a grain of salt.

OLD REVIEW BELOW:
Coming from DayZ, I can already tell this game has the kind of potential to grow into the game I wanted from the start. An engine that works well, is beautiful and has controls that feel fluid.
Simple, but clear survival mechanics. Health, food and water. No strange blood-leaking/pain-shaking/broken-gear mechanics. As much as I enjoy realism, those mechanics do not spark joy.
Enemy AI that is fun to battle against. I love Romero zombies, but they become fairly boring if in the whole town, there are 5 and you have a gun to deal with them. Scavs (as my mates call them) are currently a little silly, but super fun to fight.
Which leads to the next point.
The focus is on fighting, which I can actually respect. The best part of combat is that it's smooth and realistic. 

GUNS THAT SPAWN WITH THEIR AMMO NEXT TO THEM LIKE WHO THE F*CK HAS A SHOTGUN AND DOESN'T OWN AMMO IN THE SAME HOME.

Would recommend playing now, enjoying it with some friends, and then coming back at a later date to see the progress.

I cannot recommend Deadside to anyone that is not fully aware that this game has very little content and has had a very slow development. There are no objectives besides PVP/PVE (AI Missions). The PVP is extremely rough with latency and missing mechanics for guns. The ability to abuse the spawn system (spawning very close to your dead body). There is also a rifle that is a one hit kill to any player at any distance and through any armor removing all possibility of defending yourself. The render distance for players is also very short. The base building is very basic, it takes one player approximately 30-min to have a moderate sized base with the max storage allowed. The AI have very limited pathing and is easily abused, but they also have very aggressive aiming with full-auto weapons that will kill you from over 100M away in a burst. There are no systems in place to stop players from abusing the Safe Zone. Over all this game has potential but it needs a lot of work and time put into it. If you want to help the development process and add your feedback then absolutely purchase and play but if you are looking for your new FPS/survival shooter I cannot recommend Deadside.

okay, i've played this game off and on for the last few years and here recently the updates have been fantastic. the gameplay is wonderful. gun play is great. even base building and so on is easy depending on your base build. BUT, if you're inactive for seven days or more you lose your whole base and everything inside. My father just passed away from acute myloid leukemia so understandably i took a break( prob about 8 days). Only when i try to come back to deadside, everything i stored in my base as well as my base was gone. guns, ammo, rare armor, over 1 mil in cash, 13+ dog tags. it took me weeks to build and stock this base just to have it taken away because i haven't played in a week. it's a good game but that alone is enough to make me not even try until they wipe everything again. i don't really want to waste weeks on something i might lose if my life gets in the way of gaming. Also, there needs to be more PvE servers or more activities added to the map. the same 4 or 5 epics get old and racing people to an event just to get cussed at in chat is old. it's back to the same people doing the same things and not letting anyone else do anything other than easy missions.

The game is in early access still even though its been out nearly 2 years and has recieved almost 20 million in funding. The game lacks content theres not much to do after about three hours of playing the missions are boring and theres no need to build a base in the game because of the safe zones however if you choose to do so it will take you hours to build a small base barely big enough for three players. Majority of the game is running for 10 minutes finding some ai killing them scavenging their clothes and selling them and then repeat. Also the ai are like aimbots and will shoot you from over 100 meters away even in the pitch black night. Theres no vehicles to move across the massive map and the only form of transportation is to travel between the two safe zones which costs a ridiculous amount of grinding. Overall the game isnt worth buying as you will run out of things to do after a few hours and the dev team seems to be taking a long time to push any content out which is one of the reasons the game dies and barely comes back when content comes out. Plus most updates are small and meaningless I regret spending 20 dollars on this game it should be 15 at most theres not enough content to justify the price as well as the lack of polish on existing content.

If you roam, you will find plenty of trouble to get in to lol, and theres always heli crashes and drops to look out for.  Basebuilding looks simple but time consuming, I didnt build a base yet, I am happy with the storage at the safe zones. Honestly I was a little worried about getting this one at first... it didn't sound much different than dayz, Rust, or tarkov.

Boy was I wrong. 

It's better.

Why?

Because it takes the best of all of those games and distills crafting, looting, and base building into a simple and approachable game play loop that gets to the heart of what makes those games fun.

The devs continue to improve the game. The player community is ruthless but fun and nothing feels so hopeless when you die that you get salty. It's a very forgiving game that encourages a healthy amount of sweat.

TLDR: it's fun and pretty cheap. Get it

Overall I think this game is well put together. The graphics are nice and there is a lot of potential considering the fact this game is in its early stages. Two things off the top of my head that need improvement is: 1.) Expanded cities and or areas to explore for possible loot and action. 2.) There NEEDS to be solid, reliable and permanent servers for both PVP and PVE. If I had to pick one thing, it would be the servers. I can't think of anything more demoralizing than playing, investing time and effort only to log back in and discover that your game is completely erased because the server no longer exists. I would say get the game if you don't mind paying what it costs and then be patient.

The idea seems to be DayZ but with pvp engagements occurring every ~20 minutes instead of 2 hours.

Pros: Runs well, human AI instead of zombies, a small amount of unraidable storage in safe zones allows casual players to progress over a long period of time without playing daily

Cons: You can select which town to respawn in (too forgiving imo), the map can feel empty at times (need more POIs to explore), overall slow development cycle has lead to a lower pop than the game deserves

Game has definitely updated a good bit of stuff since I last wrote wrote a review about it. I think it's got a lot of potential honestly if they hold to their objective for it.

Pros:
-gunplay feels good and having the ability to lean is super nice 
-new spawn system on towns was a really good idea for people starting out or to recover nearby gear
-map is filling out really well with small and large landmarks all around and a nice variety of terrain
-quest pop up right and left so you always have guaranteed high tier loot to go find.
-servers have a good population size. on a pretty filled server I'd say it's fairly easy to run to towns with no quest around and loot a bit safer while you're also able to find the fights on command.
-fast travel from north to south safe zone was a really nice idea
-bases are pretty difficult to get but really worth the difficulty. I feel like it does help bases not appear absolutely everywhere though.

Only con I'd say is the game seems like it's in a fairly fragile state at the moment but if the devs hold to their plans for the game then I think it really has potential.

Great game but still needs work. The hard binding of the sprint and holding breath key is a serious pain.

Final Update: I can finally give Deadside a thumbs-up. Unfortunately, the player pool is low at the moment but the game feels right for once. Do not expect a thorough looting experience and there is alleged cheating in PVP, but the PVE experience is a blast. The fighting is intense, and the weapons handle well. The AI can be worse than players in terms of difficulty so there's plenty of action to be had, almost too much sometimes. There are still plenty of things to work out and improve on but if you have the money to burn or uninstalled this title from your library it's worth a second shot.

Update: Just played 10 months later. A better, smoother experience but still very boring. It is still a walking simulator with some random fights sprinkled in. Control defaults are still a bit funky. I really wanted to love this game but it's still not there.

Released too early. It's a free-for-all killing zone with no real direction. The idea feels like a direct rip from DayZ but amateur. Most of the houses I came across were not accessible at all and the loot system albeit clean is garbage. I had three kills in the first five minutes of playing so my lack of fun was not due to lack of competence. The in-game VOIP is set up awfully in terms of keybinding and no one seems to use it as a result. Also, 25 Sq. km was not big enough for a launch. The kill feed continues to read "[X Person] Knife [Y Person]" because combat is so frequent post spawn. Save your money for now or buy it early and hope for the best but I don't see myself reinstalling for some months at this point if ever. If you appreciate DayZ for what it tries to be you'll hate this game.

It is a fun survival game that is in the works. It is laid back compared to scum or tarkov not as much of a learning curve such as those two games but is fun because of that for me. Hopefully vehicles are implemented soon but the fast move from north to south has helped.

A great game with tons of potential. Has a nice pace lots of fun pvp is balanced. Pros:

- Pvp is fun and tense at times
- Good weapon mechanics
- Fluid movement system
- Whole base idea of the game is good
- Safe zone and trader system is well thought of, as are the missions and events
- Simple player management system that doesn't require you to ration resources as harshly like in Dayz


Cons:

- Can be buggy at times
- Scav AI is far from good
- Map seems very bland, repetitive and not many foliage variations 
- Sound design is meh, particularly directional gunshots and far gunshots, just doesn't sound right.
- Beware you cannot turn of anti-aliasing which was a problem for me as it made the game blurry meaning spotting enemies from far away was difficult

Overall i enjoyed the game, it's a nice middle ground between Dayz and Tarkov. This review is just my first impression of the game, i haven't played much so some people may have other opinions compared to mine.
